title: PCT 41: The youth who was a bony-spectre
author: Coming-Day

sentences.original: kîtahtawêh ôki nêhiyawak ôtah ,- pêhonân isiyîhkâtêw ,- êkotah êh-wîkicik, pêyak awa oskinîkiw êh-miyosit, êkwah ôhtâwiya êh-okimâwiyit, pêyakow; nam âwiya wîtisâna.
sentences.text: kîtahtawê ôki nêhiyawak ôta pêhonân isiyîhkâtêw êkota ê-wîkicik pêyak awa oskinîkiw ê-miyosit êkwa ôhtâwiya ê-okimâwiyit pêyakow nama awiya wîtisâna
sentences.english: Once upon a time when some Cree were staying right here, - Place-of-Waiting-for-Each-Other (Battleford) it is called, - there was a certain handsome youth whose father was chief, and he was an only child; he had no brothers or sisters.
So he was tenderly cared for.

sentences.original: namoy âtoskêw ta-mâcît; namoya : pikoh pisisik êh-mêtawêt, wiyâkan mistikoyâkan êwako êh-mêtawâkêt; êh-pakêsêt, isiyîhkâtêw êyakô mêtawêwin.
sentences.text: namôya atoskêw ta-mâcît namôya piko pisisik ê-mêtawêt wiyâkan mistikoyâkan êwako ê-mêtawâkêt isiyîhkâtêw êwako mêtawêwin
sentences.english: He did no work in the way of hunting; instead, he always played, and what he played with was a cup, a wooden bowl; the cup-game this game is called.

sentences.original: mâka mistahi sâkihtâw ôma mistikoyâkan, êkâ kâ-mêtawêt pikoh êh-pîmakâmêskahk ôma, ahpôh êh-nipât âskaw êh-kikiskahk.
sentences.text: mâka mistahi sâkihtâw ôma mistikoyâkan êkâ kâ-mêtawêt piko ê-pîmakâmêskahk ôma ahpô ê-nipât âskaw ê-kikiskahk
sentences.english: He was very much devoted to this wooden bowl; when he was not playing, he wore it on a strap round his shoulder, and even when he slept he sometimes kept it on his person.

sentences.original: kîtahtawê ôm êkotah êh-wa-wîkicik, kâ-pâpiciyit wâhyaw ohci sakâw-iyinîsah, mâka êh-macihtwâyit, êh-manitôwiyit.
sentences.text: kîtahtawê ôma êkota ê-wa-wîkicik kâ-pâpiciyit wâhyaw ohci sakâw-iyinîsa mâka ê-macihtwâyit ê-manitôwiyit
sentences.english: Then at one time, as they made a long stay here, one of those Bush-Fellows moved his camp here from afar, and he was one who practised evil, and a manitou person.

sentences.original: êkwah êh-âh-atâwêyit, atâwêwikamikoh tohtêwak êh-nisticik oskinîkiwak.
sentences.text: êkwa ê-âh-atâwêyit atâwêwikamikohk itohtêwak ê-nisticik oskinîkiwak
sentences.english: Then, when he was doing his trading, three young men went to the trading-post.
Presently some young women came into the house.

sentences.original: êkwah ôhi kisêyiniwa pôtih nisto tawâsimisiyiwa, mistahih atâwâkanah êh-pîhtokahâyit.
sentences.text: êkwa ôhi kisêyiniwa pôti nisto otawâsimisiyiwa mistahi atâwâkana ê-pîhtokahâyit
sentences.english: It appeared that they were the old man's three daughters, and they were bringing a great store of furs into the post.

sentences.original: sêmâk ôh ôsîmimâwa akâwâtêw awa kâh-mêtawêsit.
sentences.text: sêmâk ôhi osîmimâwa akâwâtêw awa kâ-mêtawêsit
sentences.english: At once he who was addicted to that game took a fancy to the youngest woman.

sentences.original: tâpwê miyosiw, nîscâs! itêw ôhi kâ-wîcîwât.
sentences.english: “Really, she is beautiful, Cousin!” he said to those who were, with him.
At last they went home.

sentences.original: niscâs, tâpwê mistahi nitakâwâtâw aw iskwêw itêw.
sentences.english: “Cousin, really, I very much desire this woman!” he said to them.

sentences.original: yôw, nîscâs! âyimisiwak êh-macihtwâcik sakâw-iyiniwak; kitisi-pêhtênânaw mâna.
sentences.english: “Dear me, Cousin! The Bush People who practise evil magic are bad to deal with; we always hear this said.
Why do you fancy just her?

sentences.original: iyâtah_mêyikawiyini iskwêwak, namoya kitâpwêhtên, itêw wîscâsah.
sentences.english: When people want to give you women to wife, you do not accept,” said the one to his cousin.
“Oh, Cousin, but I am in love with her!” he answered him.

sentences.original: êkos êh-tipiskâyik, nôhtâh, maht êwakôw âna nitom kisêyiniw.
sentences.english: So then, that evening, “Father, please invite that old man.
I am in love with that daughter of his,” he said to him.
“Dear me!” cried the old man;

sentences.original: nkosis, tânêhki kacâc nâtakâm kâ-wîh-wîwiyan, êyakw âwa êh-macihtwât, êh-itikot wîci-sakâw-iyiniwa, êh-mantôwit, êh-iskwâhât otôtêmah opawâmiwinihk ohci ? itik ôhtâwiya.
sentences.english: “My son, why must you just take a wife from the north, and just from this man who practises evil magic, as his fellow-Bush-People say of him, this man who has spirit power and kills off his fellow tribesmen through his dream helpers?” his father asked him.

sentences.original: hâ, mâka êkwêyâk ntakâwâtâw iskwêw! itwêw.
sentences.english: “Oh, but it is only now that I long for any woman!” he said.
“Well, wait a bit! Let me first inquire,” said his father;

sentences.original: êh, kikitimâkêyimitin mâka, nikosis, pikoh t-âtâwêyân, itêw.
sentences.english: “But I love and cherish you, my son, and there is nothing for me to do but buy her,” he told him.
sentences.footnote: LB on {t-âtâwêyân}: The word is {atâwêw}: “he trades (especially furs against White Man's products)”; I do not know whether it can bear the meaning I have given in the translation, or how else it may fit here.

sentences.original: êkwah ntomêwak oskinîkiw-sakâw-iyinîsah, êh-kakwêcimâcik, mahtih t-onâpêmiyit.
sentences.text: êkwa nitomêwak oskinîkiwi-sakâw-iyinîsa ê-kakwêcimâcik mahti ta-onâpêmiyit
sentences.english: Then they called in a young Bush-Fellow and asked him whether those girls had husbands.
“They are not married.

sentences.original: omisimâw ana nîswâw onâpêmiw; êkwah ana tastawiyask pêyakwâw onâpêmiw; an ôsîmimâw namoya cêskwa onâpêmiw.
sentences.english: That oldest one has twice been married; and the middle one has been married once; the youngest one has never had a husband.

sentences.original: mâka mistah êh-macihtwât ana kisêyiniw, niyân ôma kâ-sakâwiyiniwiyâhk êh-kostâyâhk ta-wîcêmâyâhk otânisah.
sentences.english: But as the old man is a great sorcerer, the fact is that we Bush Folk are afraid to consort with his daughters.

sentences.original: nistwâw êh-onahâhkisîmit, aspin mâna pêskêpicitwâwi, iyikoh niyîpihkih wê-wâpamihtwâwi, kayahtê namoya wîcêwêwak onahâhkisîmiwâwa.
sentences.english: Three sons-in-law he has had, and each time, when off they went to camp by themselves, and then in spring were seen again, to our surprise their son-in-law was not with them.
And so it is not known in what way they destroyed them.
When they are asked, they will not tell,” he told them.
The youth longed for her none the less.

sentences.original: êkosi âhci pikoh sîhkimêw ôhtâwiya, ta-ntomâyit kisêyiniwa, ta-ntotamawâyit otânisiyiwa.
sentences.text: êkosi âhci piko sîhkimêw ôhtâwiya ta-nitomâyit kisêyiniwa ta-nitotamawâyit otânisiyiwa
sentences.english: So he kept urging his father to invite the old man and ask him for his daughter.

sentences.original: piyis tâpwê ntawi-ntomêw awa kisêyiniw ôhi sakâw-iyiniwah.
sentences.text: piyis tâpwê nitawi-nitomêw awa kisêyiniw ôhi sakâw-iyiniwa
sentences.english: At last the old man really did go and invite that Bush Cree.

sentences.original: êh-pîhtokêyit, ômis îtêw, êh-kîsi-mîcisocik : hâw, ntôtêm, k-ôh-natomitân, pêyak oskinîkiskwêw êh-akâwâtamâtân.
sentences.english: When the latter came to the tent, he spoke thus to him, after they had eaten: “Now, Fellow-Tribesman, the reason I have invited you is because I want one of the young women.
It appears that you have three young women,” he said to him;

sentences.original: niyân wiya ôtêh paskwâhk k-âyâwâyâhk ,- êkoyikohk miyo-atimêw mostoswah, iyikohk êh-ispisît ,- êwako kimiyitin, miyiyini kitânis.
sentences.english: “That creature which we have here in the Plains Country, - then does he well pursue the buffalo, when he has his growth, - such a one I give you, if you give me your daughter.
sentences.footnote: LB on {êwako}:  He makes a circumlocution, instead of using the word “horse.”  This may be the same word-avoidance as that which I met; the old man is talking, if not to a foreigner, at least to a member of a different branch of the Cree tribe, of a markedly different dialect.

sentences.english: It is not I that wish to consort with her, but my son wishes to consort with her.
He is not here; he has gone out.
But, wishing to be married to her, 'Do ask him,' he has said to me,” he told him.

sentences.original: yahô, ntôtêm, niy âni wiya nikah-miywêyihtên, paskwâw-iyiniw tit-ôtêmiyân.
sentences.english: “Hoho, Fellow-Tribesman, as for me, I shall be glad to have an animal like the Plains Cree.
sentences.footnote: LB on {tit-ôtêmiyân}:  The word here is {otêmiw}: “he has a horse, dog, or other familiar animal”.  Probably the form in the text is an error of speech or record for {tit-otôtêmiyân}, from {otôtêmiw}: “he has a kinsman,” and the sentence should be translated, “to have a Plains Cree in my family.” Cf. the next note.

sentences.original: tâpwê mâka niyanân itêh k-ôtaskiyâhk ma-manêpayiwak misatimwak, itêw;
sentences.english: Truly there where we others dwell, there is a lack of horses,” he told him;
“I cannot at this time tell you anything, Fellow-Tribesman.

sentences.original: wiya tipêyimêw otawâsimisah ninôtokêm; wiya kih-âyimihik ê-wîh-ohpikihât, itêw;
sentences.english: It is my wife who has decision over her children; it is to her they gave trouble when she labored to bring them up,” he told him;
“Let us see what she thinks; I shall tell her of this,” he told him.
Then they conversed of other things.

sentences.original: iyikohk êh-kîwêt awa sakâw-iyiniw, êh-pîhtokêt, yahah, nôtokêsiw, kâ-ntomit awa paskwâw-iyiniw, êh-ntotamawit kitânisinawa.
sentences.english: When the Bush Cree went home, and entered his tent, “Yah, Wife, this Plains Cree invited me to ask me for our daughter.
We are to be given one horse;

sentences.original: mâka kiya êh-tipahitân, ê-kîh-âyimihiskik, ê-wih-ohpikihacik kitawâsimisinawak, itêw.
sentences.english: but it is by you I shall guide myself, since it was to you our children gave trouble when you labored to bring them up,” he said to her.
“Goodness, do let us give her, then!

sentences.original: wiyâyêpac wiya otôtêmiyahk! itwêw awa nôtokêsiw.
sentences.english: We ought to be glad to have him in our family!” said the old woman.
sentences.footnote: LB on {otôtêmiyahk}:  Perhaps the reverse of the preceding error, for {otêmiyahk or tit-ôtêmiyahk}: “to have such an animal”.

sentences.original: êkos êh-wâpaniyik, kisâkamisikê, nôtokêsiw; nka-ntawi-ntomâw paskwâw-iyiniw, itêw.
sentences.english: So, the next morning, “Prepare hot water, Wife; I am going to invite the Plains Cree,” he told her.
So he went and invited him.

sentences.original: êh-wâpamât awa kisêyiniw, pôtih mistahi miyosiyiwa ôh ôskinîkiskwêwa.
sentences.text: ê-wâpamât awa kisêyiniw pôti mistahi miyosiyiwa ôhi oskinîkiskwêwa
sentences.english: When that old man saw her, he saw that the young woman was very beautiful.
“No wonder, I see, that my son fell in love with her!” he thought.

sentences.original: êkwah ê-kîh-mîcisocik, ntôtêm, anima kâ-kîh-isiyan tipiskohk, miywêyihtam awa ninôtokêm;
sentences.english: Then, when they had eaten, “My fellow-tribesman, my wife is pleased with that which you said to me last night;

sentences.original: têpêyimôw pêyak otânisah t-âyâyit paskwâwiyinînâhk, êh-itwêt.
sentences.english: she is content that one of her daughters stay in the Plains Cree country, she says.”
Then that old man gave thanks.

sentences.original: tân êwakw êtokê mâka, ntôtêm ? itêw.
sentences.english: “But which one is it, Fellow-Tribesman?” he asked him.

sentences.original: â, tân ân êwako wêsîmimâwit, êwako kâ-nôhtê-wîcêwât nikosis, itêw.
sentences.english: Oh, the one who is the youngest; she is the one whom my son desires to take to wife,” he told them.

sentences.original: êkosi mâna mâka, ntôtêm, otâkosiki t-êtohtêw nitânis.
sentences.english: “So then, Follow-Tribesman, this evening my daughter will go there.
First she will have to do a little sewing,” he told him.
Then the old man went back home.

sentences.original: êh-pîhtokêt, hâ, nkosis, kimiyikawin ana kâ-ntawêyimat, itêw okosisah.
sentences.english: When he entered the tipi, “Well, my son, the one you love is given to you,” he said to his son.
The youth rejoiced.

sentences.original: iyikohk êh-otâkosiniyik, êkoyikohk pê-wîcêwêw otânisah awa nôtokêsiw, êh-pê-nayahtahkik ayôwinisah, kikih ocayânisah aw oskinîkiskwêw; ayis anohc piko mistahih atâwêw awa kisêyiniw.
sentences.text: iyikohk ê-otâkosiniyik êkoyikohk pê-wîcêwêw otânisa awa nôtokêsiw ê-pê-nayahtahkik ayiwinisa kiki ocayânisa awa oskinîkiskwêw ayis anohc piko mistahi atâwêw awa kisêyiniw
sentences.english: When evening came, that old woman came with her daughter, and they carried a burden of clothes and the young woman's belongings; for, only a short time before, that old man had traded much at the post.

sentences.original: êkosi pîhtokêw awa, tit-êsi-miyikot aw oskinîkiw, êh-kaskikwâtamoht;
sentences.text: êkosi pîhtokêw awa tita-isi-miyikot awa oskinîkiw ê-kaskikwâtamoht
sentences.english: So she entered, and they gave the youth what had been sewn for him;
they were surprised  at the fine clothes he wore because his father was a chief.
As he had promised, he gave one horse;
really, he took her to wife.
They camped there for a long time.

sentences.original: piyisk kotakak ayîsiyiniwak pâh-piciwak, mîna kayâs kâ-nakatiht awa kisêyiniw sakâw-iyiniw, otôtêma ê-kîh-piciyit, êh-ka-kisâtât otânisah.
sentences.text: piyisk kotakak ayîsiyiniwak pâh-piciwak mîna kayâs kâ-nakatiht awa kisêyiniw sakâw-iyiniw otôtêma ê-kî-piciyit ê-ka-kisâtât otânisa
sentences.english: After a while the other people, one by one, moved camp, until it was long since the old Bush Cree had been left as the last, staying on with his daughter after his fellow-tribesmen had moved away.
Then at one time he called his daughter's father-in-law.

sentences.original: ê-pîhtokêyit, ê-kîh-ma-mîcisocik, yôh, nitihtâwâw, êkoyikohk ôma k-êspîhtâwahk, êkwah mâna niyânân kâ-mâci-nôtatâwâkanêyahk, itêw;
sentences.english: When the latter had entered, and when they had eaten, “Now, my fellow-father-in-law, the time has come now when we others always go out to hunt for furs,” he told him;

sentences.original: ninôhtê-nâtakâsin; êkwah êkoyikohk kinwêsk êh-kisâtitân, itêw;
sentences.english: “I want to go to the Bush Country; this is as long as I can stay with you,” he told him;

sentences.original: êkosi mâka niya mîna kiyipah kê-piciyân;
sentences.english: “So now I too shall soon move camp;

sentences.original: êkoyikohk nîstah êh-ihkêyihtamân, kayâs kâ-nakacipicistawicik ntôtêmak, itêw;
sentences.english: I think it long enough now, since long ago my fellow-tribesmen have moved camp and left me behind,” he told him;

sentences.original: êkosi ômisi ntêyihtên, itwêw awa kisêyiniw sakâw-iyiniw;
sentences.english: “And so this is my idea,” said the old Bush Cree;

sentences.original: ntihtâwâw, pitah nâtakâm nnôhtê-isi-wîcêwâw ninahâhkisîm, ta-kiskinôhamawak sakâwi-mâcîwin, nôcihcikêwin, itêw;
sentences.english: “Fellow-Father-in-Law, for a while I should like to take my son-in-law along to the North Country, to teach him the woodland way of hunting and getting furs,” he told him;

sentences.original: itâp nîpinisiyâhkoh, êkoyikohk kiyaskociwâw ka-pamihikowâw kistimiwâw, itêw.
sentences.english: “When we come  back to summer camp, then you, in return, will have the service of  your daughter-in-law,” he told him.
“Very well.”

sentences.original: âta pakwâtam; mâka kostêw ôh ôtihtâwâwa, mâna oka-nta-misi-wanâcihoh! êh-itêyimât okosisah.
sentences.text: âta pakwâtam mâka kostêw ôhi otihtâwâwa ê-itêyimât okosisa
sentences.english: To be sure, he disliked the plan; but he feared this man, his son's father-in-law, thinking of his son, “If only he does not go to his destruction!”
When he came home, he announced that the others were going to move camp.

sentences.original: pitah nistim ta-ntawâpamêw, ta-wîhtamawât, ta-pêhikoyêk, itêw.
sentences.english: “My daughter-in-law had better first go see them and tell them to wait for you,” he told them.
So then the young woman left the tipi.
“Oh, my son, it is a dangerous place where you are to stay with your wife's people.
We hear that your father-in-law is a sorcerer and a person of manitou power.
Do for a time give up your game.

sentences.original: itâp iyikohk takosiniyini ôtê, kika-ma-mêtawân, itêw;
sentences.english: When you come back here, you may play as much as you like,” he told him;
“Do your utmost not to anger your father  in-law.

sentences.original: âhkamêyimoh, iskoh kaskihtâyan, kîkway ta-kakwê-nipahtâyan, itêw okosisah;
sentences.english: Gather your energies, as far as you are able, and make an effort to kill things,” he told his son;

sentences.original: ât âni kisâkihitin; mâka nikostâw kimanâcimâkan, êh-manâh-kisiwâhak, itêw.
sentences.english: “I hate to let you go; but I fear your father-in-law, and should dread to displease him,” he said  to him.
Accordingly they made themselves ready to move camp.
And so in two different directions they went from there.
The Bush Cree took his son-in-law away with him.
Oh, the old man liked that.

sentences.original: iyikohk nâtakâm êh-ayâcik, êkoyikohk ati-mâh-mâcîw awa kisêyiniw, êh-wîcêwât onahâhkisîma, ê-kiskinôhamawât tânisi tit-êsi-mitihtâyit pisiskiwah.
sentences.text: iyikohk nâtakâm ê-ayâcik êkoyikohk ati-mâh-mâcîw awa kisêyiniw ê-wîcêwât onahâhkisîma ê-kiskinôhamawât tânisi tita-isi-mitihtâyit pisiskiwa
sentences.english: As soon as they were in the wooded country, the old man kept hunting as they went on, taking his son-in-law with him and teaching him to track the game.
In time the young man became skilled.

sentences.original: hâ, pêyakôw êkwah, êh-mâh-mâcît, môswah êh-mâcîtotawât, nanâtohk pisiskiwah êh-nôcihât.
sentences.text: hâ pêyakôw êkwa ê-mâh-mâcît môswa ê-mâcîtotawât nanâtohk pisiskiwa ê-nôcihât
sentences.english: So now he went alone, as he continued to hunt, hunting moose and pursuing all kinds of game.

sentences.original: êkâh miyâcîci, kîtahtawêh mâna, mêtawêtân! êh-itikot owîkimâkana, min ôhi wîtimwah êh-pakêsîcik, piyisk miywêyihtamwak ôk ôskinîkiskwêwak.
sentences.text: êkâ miyâcîci kîtahtawê mâna ê-itikot owîkimâkana mîna ôhi wîtimwa ê-pakêsêcik piyisk miywêyihtamwak ôki oskinîkiskwêwak
sentences.english: When he was not hunting, presently always, “Let us play!” his wife would say to him, and then they, as well as his sisters-in-law, would play the cup-game, until, in time, those young women became fond of it.

sentences.original: âta wiyah namoya tahkih êyisâc êh-pônihtât mâna aw oskinîkiw.
sentences.text: âta wiya namôya tahki iyisâc ê-pônihtât mâna awa oskinîkiw
sentences.english: Indeed, the young man was always loth to cease from it.

sentences.original: piyisk êh-atih-piponiyik, hâh, êkoyikohk ôma êspîhtâwahkih, êkotê kâ-mawacihitohk, itwêw awa kisêyiniw.
sentences.english: Then, in time, as the winter went on, “Now then, the time has come when the band assembles over yonder,” said the old man.
Then they moved camp to that place.
By this time they had food for the journey.

sentences.original: têpwê pâpiciwak it êh-ayâcik kotakak sakâw-iyiniwak.
sentences.text: tâpwê pâpiciwak ita ê-ayâcik kotakak sakâw-iyiniwak
sentences.english: They came to where the other Bush People were staying.

sentences.original: âh, miywêyimâw awa paskwâw-iyiniw, êkotê êh-takosihk.
sentences.text: â miywêyimâw awa paskwâw-iyiniw êkotê ê-takosihk
sentences.english: The Plains Cree was liked when he came there.

sentences.original: cîhkêyimik oskinîkiwa, mâka êh-itikot, âyiman ânih!
sentences.english: Another young man became his friend, but he told him, “It is a hard thing!
Why are you staying here with your wife's people?
He is really a hard man to be with.

sentences.original: âtah, k-êtêyihtamiyit awiya, âsay ê-misi-wanâcihât awa kisis.
sentences.english: Even though one thinks, 'I am doing nothing serious,' before one knows it, this father-in-law of yours has done for him.

sentences.original: mîna nistwâw kiw-onahâhkisîmiw; ati-misi-wanâcihêwak, itêw, ôh êh-itikot oskinîkiwa;
sentences.english: He has had three sons-in-law before you; one after another they have destroyed them,” he told him, that youth told him;

sentences.original: awahê kakwê êkâ wiya kisiwâh kisis;
sentences.english: “Be on your guard and try not to incur your father-in-law's displeasure;

sentences.original: âyimanohk ôma kâ-wîkihkêmoyan, an âna mîna kîtim omisimâw ê-wîcôhkamawât ôhtâwiya, êh-macihtwâyit, ê-mantôwicik.
sentences.english: it is in a dangerous place you are, staying with your wife's people, for that oldest sister-in-law of yours, too, makes common cause with her father in his bad magic, and both have manitou power.”

sentences.original: êkosi êkwah êkotah ayâwak, iyikohk êh-mawacihitocik, êh-mihcêtisicik, nanâtohk êh-âh-isih-wîhkohtocik, mîna êh-nîmihitocik.
sentences.text: êkosi êkwa êkota ayâwak iyikohk ê-mâwacîhitocik ê-mihcêtisicik nanâtohk ê-âh-isi-wîhkohtocik mîna ê-nîmihitocik
sentences.english: So there they stayed, when the band had assembled in great number, inviting one another to all manner of feasts, and dancing religious dances.

sentences.original: wiya oskinîkiw kîtahtawê pêyak wîhkayimik oskinîkiwa, pisisik êh-kiyôkâkot.
sentences.text: wiya oskinîkiw kîtahtawê pêyak cîhkêyimik oskinîkiwa pisisik ê-kiyokâkot
sentences.english: In time a certain other young man became fond of this youth and constantly visited him.

sentences.original: mâka ôhi wîtimwa tahkih mawinêhok, ê-pakêsîcik.
sentences.text: mâka ôhi wîtimwa tahki mawinêhok ê-pakêsêcik
sentences.english: His sisters-in-law kept bothering him to play the cup-game with them.
For they did no hunting, but were busy with feasting one another.

sentences.original: piyisk awa oskinîkiw k-ô-kâ-kah-kiyokêt, êyako mîna kiskêyihtam êh-mêtawêt, piyisk êh-wîhtamawât kotakah oskinîkiwah êh-ayât awah paskwâw-iyiniw pakêsêwiyâkan.
sentences.text: piyisk awa oskinîkiw kâ-ôh-kâ-ka-kiyokêt êwako mîna kiskêyihtam ê-mêtawêt piyisk ê-wîhtamawât kotaka oskinîkiwa ê-ayât awa paskwâw-iyiniw pakêsêwiyâkan
sentences.english: After a time that young man who kept visiting them had, he too, learned the game, and in time told the other young men that the Plains Cree had a bowl for the cup-game.

sentences.original: kîtahtawê mâna pîhtokêyiwa oskinîkiwa, ê-wîh-kiskinawâpahtamiyit ôma omêtawêwin, ê-kiskinôhamawât;
sentences.text: kîtahtawê mâna pîhtokêyiwa oskinîkiwa ê-wî-kiskinawâpahtamiyit ôma omêtawêwin ê-kiskinôhamawât
sentences.english: Presently some young man would always be coming into the tipi, to learn that game of his by looking on, and he would teach it to him;
in time the other would learn it;

sentences.original: piyis mâna ntomâw êkotê êh-mêtawêcik, ê-kiskinôhamawât oskinîkiwa;
sentences.text: piyis mâna nitomâw êkotê ê-mêtawêcik ê-kiskinôhamawât oskinîkiwa
sentences.english: in time he would be invited to come where they were playing and teach it to the young men;

sentences.original: piyisk kâ-kapê-kîsik mêtawêw, nêtê kâ-kîsi-miywêyihtahk pisisik kâ-kîh-mêtawêt.
sentences.text: piyisk kâ-kapê-kîsik mêtawêw nêtê kâ-kîsi-miywêyihtahk pisisik kâ-kî-mêtawêt
sentences.english: presently he was playing all day and every day, with the same addiction that had kept him always a-playing in his home off yonder.
That was what he did, he played all the time.
The time came when the others, at intervals, moved camp.

sentences.original: piyis êkwah nâh-nôhtêhkatêwak; ayis ôma kâ-wâh-wîhkohtocik mistahi mêscipayihtâwak mîciwin.
sentences.text: piyis êkwa nâh-nôhtêhkatêwak ayis ôma kâ-wâh-wîhkohtocik mistahi mêscipayihtâwak mîciwin
sentences.english: By and by, too, they began to go hungry; for in their feasting one another they had used up much food.

sentences.original: kîtahtawê êkwah awa kisêyiniw tân-tahto kîsikâw êkwah êkâ kêkway tâpwê êh-mîcit, ê-kisâtât onahâhkisîma, pisisik êh-mêtawêyit, kîtahtawê nîsotipiskwah êh-mêtawêyit, êkoyikohk kisiwâsiw awa kisêyiniw.
sentences.text: kîtahtawê êkwa awa kisêyiniw tânitahto kîsikâw êkwa êkâ kêkway tâpwê ê-mîcit ê-kisâtât onahâhkisîma pisisik ê-mêtawêyit kîtahtawê nîsotipiskwa ê-mêtawêyit êkoyikohk kisiwâsiw awa kisêyiniw
sentences.english: Then at one time, when for I know not how many days that old man had not eaten anything to speak of, as he stayed there with his son-in-law who did nothing but play, then at one time, when the latter had been a-playing for two days and nights, at last the old man lost patience.

sentences.original: ômis îtwêw : êkoyikohk kinwêsk êy-isîtôwihak paskwâw-iyiniw, kâ-nôhtêhkatêyahk.
sentences.english: Said he: “Long enough now have I supported the Plains Cree, seeing that now we are starving.
Let us move camp,” he told the others;
“Let him eat that toy of his.
When I kill game, you are not to feed him.

sentences.original: wîstah nipahtâci kîkwayah, êkoyikohk ta-mîcisôw, itêw onahâhkisîma.
sentences.english: When he kills something, then he can eat,” he said of his son-in-law.

sentences.original: êh-kîkisêpâyâyik, mistahi pakwâtam aw oskinîkiskwêw êh-itimiht owîkimâkana.
sentences.text: ê-kîkisêpâyâyik mistahi pakwâtam awa oskinîkiskwêw ê-itimiht owîkimâkana
sentences.english: When morning came, that young woman was greatly distressed by what had been said concerning her husband.
Secretly she wept.
So then he learned that his people were getting ready to leave.
Where they were gaming, the players learned of it.
“The Plains Cree's people are moving their camp,” he was told.
“Dear me!” said that Bush Cree;

sentences.original: ntôtêm, âyimisiw ana; namoy âni okisêwâtisiwiniw.
sentences.english: “Fellow-Tribesman, he is a dangerous person; he has no kindliness at all.
If anything angers him, he is dangerous.
He has no kindliness toward anything.

sentences.original: asây ani êh-kisiwâhat, êkâ oh-pih-wîhtamâkawiyin ê-wîh-picit.
sentences.english: You have already incurred his displeasure: that is why you were not sent the message that he is about to break camp.
Without delay, if you have any knowledge beyond the common, try to gather your energies.
He is a manitou person, I tell you!” that man said to him.
“If that is the case, he has done for me.
I have no mystic knowledge.
I have not dreamed anything.
If it is as you say, he will soon kill me,” said he.
So then, when four nights had passed, he went away.
He came to a place where the others evidently had camped.
He kept on walking.
When he had passed two of their overnight camping places, he saw where they had killed game.
When he overtook them, at nightfall, there he saw the meat.

sentences.original: êkos êcik âni kê-mîcisoyân! nnôhtêhkatâh! itêyihtam.
sentences.english: “So now I shall get a meal! I am hungry enough!” he thought.

sentences.original: mâka ômisi kîh-itwêw awa kisêyiniw : iyikohk kêkway nipahtâci paskwâw-iyiniw, ta-mîcisôw.
sentences.english: But the old man had spoken thus: “When the Plains kills anything, then let him eat.
Even though he arrives, do not give him food.
I shall be sure to know it, if you feed him secretly,” he said.
All feared him, his children and his wife.

sentences.original: êkwah awa oskinîkiw kâh-pîhtokêt, wâpahtam kâhkêwakwah êh-akotêyikih.
sentences.text: êkwa awa oskinîkiw kâ-pîhtokêt wâpahtam kâhkêwakwa ê-akotêyiki
sentences.english: When the young man entered, he saw the pieces of parched meat hanging.
So he sat there.

sentences.original: piyis namoya wâpahtam ta-wîh-kakwê-asamiht, ê-ka-kâmwâtapiyit owîkimâkana.
sentences.text: piyis namôya wâpahtam ta-wî-kakwê-asamiht ê-ka-kâmwâtapiyit owîkimâkana
sentences.english: At last he did not see that there was any intention of feeding him, and his wife sat silent and gloomy.

sentences.original: piyisk, tawasimisitik, mahtih kâhkêwakwah nawacîk, ta-kawisimôw-mîcisoyahk, êh-itât, tâpwê nawacîwak ôma kâhkêwak.
sentences.text: piyisk ê-itât tâpwê nawacîwak ôma kâhkêwak
sentences.english: In time, “Children, roast some dried meat for our bedtime meal,” he said to them, and so they roasted a piece of dried meat.
Then, when they ate, he was given no food at all.

sentences.original: êh-ât-âsamimiht owîkimâkana, nama wîh-mîcisoyiwa, kiyâm nîstah nka-nipahâhkatoson, êh-itêyihtamiyit.
sentences.english: His wife was given some, but she would not eat, thinking, “Let me too starve.”

sentences.original: yahô, ntânis, mîcisoh! namoya ka-kîh-kisîstên mîciwin! itwêyiwa.
sentences.english: “Hoho, Daughter, eat! You cannot go without food!” said the other.

sentences.original: tâpwê mîcisôw; namoy âsamêw onâpêma, ê-kostât ôhtâwiya.
sentences.text: tâpwê mîcisôw namôya asamêw onâpêma ê-kostât ôhtâwiya
sentences.english: Accordingly she ate; she did not give her husband food, for she feared her father.
At last they went to bed, even so.
When they had gone to bed, the woman kissed her husband.
“My husband, perhaps you have some mystic knowledge.
Summon your forces, that you may kill something.

sentences.original: êh-kitahamât ôma nôhtâwiy êkâ t-âsamikawiyin, êkosi ê-kostâyâhk kahkiyaw.
sentences.english: The fact is that my father has forbidden your being given any food, and we all stand in fear of him.
To no avail am I distressed at what is being done to you, for I love you.

sentences.original: ôk ôki nimisak êyâta-ônâpêmitwâwi, êkos êh-tôtâhcik ôma kâ-wîh-tôtâkawiyan, êh-nipahâhkatosocik.
sentences.english: When these my elder sisters here had husbands, this was done to them which is about to be done to you, and they died of hunger.

sentences.original: êkwah êh-mantôwit nôhtâwiy, namoy âwiya wîhkâc êh-sâkôcihikot.
sentences.english: Because my father is a manitou person, he is never defeated by anyone.
I love you.
Try to kill some food for yourself,” she told him.

sentences.original: êhâ, êkos âna kê-nipahit kôhtâwiy! namoya kêkway nikiskêyihtên, itêw.
sentences.english: “Oh, if that is so, then your father will kill me! I have no mystic knowledge,” he told her.
sentences.footnote: LB on {namoya}:  The normal combination is {nama kêkway}: “nothing”; here the more general negative {namoya} is used, probably because {kêkway kiskêyihtam}: “he knows something” has here the specialized sense of “he has mystic knowledge.”

sentences.original: êkosi mâtôw aw oskinîkiskwêw, êh-itikot owîkimâkana.
sentences.text: êkosi mâtôw awa oskinîkiskwêw ê-itikot owîkimâkana
sentences.english: Then the young wife wept, when her husband said this to her.
So they went to sleep.
In the morning, when again the family ate, he was not given food.

sentences.original: êkos îsi êh-kîsi-mîcisôwiht, piko ta-piciyahk! itwêyiwa.
sentences.english: When in this way his people had eaten, “We must move camp!” said that other.
So then he went out of the tent and hunted.

sentences.original: iyâtah-kîkway-wâpahtahki, wâh-nipahtâci, kîkway pêhtam, êh-tapasiyit ôhi kâ-wîh-nipahât.
sentences.text: iyâta-kîkway-wâpahtahki wâh-nipahtâci kîkway pêhtam ê-tapasîyit ôhi kâ-wî-nipahât
sentences.english: Although he would get sight of things, whenever he was about to kill them, he would hear something, and the creature he was going to kill would run away.
Even though he shot at nothing more than a rabbit, he did not kill it.

sentences.original: êkosi pihîs mâna aspin tê k-êspiciwiht êh-itohtêt, têkohtêci, êkos êh-ay-apit, namoy âsamâw.
sentences.text: êkosi piyis mâna aspin itê kâ-ispiciwiht ê-itohtêt têkohtêci êkosi ê-ay-apit namôya asamâw
sentences.english: When then at last he would go to where his people had moved the camp, when he arrived, and sat there, he was not given food.

sentences.original: âtah tahto-kîsikâw êh-mâcît, mâka nama kêkway kîh-nipahtâw.
sentences.text: âta tahto-kîsikâw ê-mâcît mâka nama kêkway kî-nipahtâw
sentences.english: Although he hunted every day, he did not succeed in killing anything.
How weak he grew with hunger!

sentences.original: piyis mâna mistahi nîpâhtêw, êkwah ê-kawâhkatosot.
sentences.text: piyis mâna mistahi nîpâhtêw êkwa ê-kawâhkatosot
sentences.english: At last he took to walking much in the dark, so far gone with hunger was he.

sentences.original: kîtahtawê êkwah namoya kîh-mâcîw, êkwah êh-kawâhkatosot, pêciwihci, êh-apit mâtokâhpihk, wîhkâc iyikohk mâna ê-sipwêhtêt.
sentences.text: kîtahtawê êkwa namôya kî-mâcîw êkwa ê-kawâhkatosot pêciwihci ê-apit matokahpihk wîhkâc iyikohk mâna ê-sipwêhtêt
sentences.english: Then in time he became unable to hunt, for the weakness of hunger, and when they moved camp he would sit on the deserted site, able only at intervals to move himself from the spot.
Then at one time, as he came into the tipi, he fell to the ground, exhausted by starvation.

sentences.original: yahôw, tânisi wiy êkwah paskwâw-iyiniw tiyotahk ? itêw onahâhkisîma, êh-pâhpihât.
sentences.english: “Oho, what is the Plainsman doing now, pray?” said the man to his son-in-law, in derision.

sentences.original: mâtôw aw oskinîkiskwêw, êh-ocipitât onâpêma, êkwah ê-wîh-nipahâhkatosoyit.
sentences.text: mâtôw awa oskinîkiskwêw ê-ocipitât onâpêma êkwa ê-wî-nipahâhkatosoyit
sentences.english: The young wife wept, and drew her husband to her, her husband who was about to die of hunger.

sentences.original: yâh! itwêw awa kisêyiniw, êh-wâpamât êh-mâtoyit otânisah;
sentences.text: itwêw awa kisêyiniw ê-wâpamât ê-mâtoyit otânisa
sentences.english: “Bah!” said that old man, when he saw that his daughter wept;

sentences.original: kêkway ôma mêwihkâtaman ? kiyâm apih! itêw.
sentences.english: “What are you weeping about? Be still!” he told her.
So she ceased her lamenting.
The woman sat where her husband lay.
He was dying of hunger.

sentences.original: êkwah êkotah kîh-pîmoyôw apsîs kâhkêwakos, iyikohk êh-kawisimocik êh-asamât onâpêma, hâh, tânik ôma miscahîs mîciyân! êh-itêyihtahk aw ôskinîkiw.
sentences.text: êkwa êkota kî-pîmoyôw apisîs kâhkêwakos iyikohk ê-kawisimocik ê-asamât onâpêma ê-itêyihtahk awa oskinîkiw
sentences.english: She had slipped into the bosom-fold of her garment a tiny bit of parched meat, and gave it to her husband when they went to bed, and, “Would I could only eat a little more of this!” was the young man's thought.
But he was certain to starve to death.

sentences.original: êtataw an êkwah ntakohtân, niwîkimâkan, itêw;
sentences.english: “It was only with a last effort that this time I arrived, my wife,” he told her;
“And so your father is starving me to death.

sentences.original: matwân_cî nka-takohtân, itêh êkwah kapêsiyêkoh ? itêw.
sentences.english: It is not likely that I shall arrive at your next night's camping place,” he told her.
Oh, the young wife wept.

sentences.original: hâw, kîspin misi-wanâtisiyinih, nîstah namoya wîhkâc nka-mîcison, itik owîkimâkana.
sentences.english: “Oh, if you come to grief, I too shall never eat,” his wife answered him.

sentences.original: êkos îsi âta êh-wîh-kakwê-nipât, mâka nama ta-kîh-nipât, êyikohk êh-nôhtêhkatêt.
sentences.text: êkosi isi âta ê-wî-kakwê-nipât mâka nama ta-kî-nipât iyikohk ê-nôhtêhkatêt
sentences.english: Then, though he wanted to go to sleep, he could not sleep, so hungry was he.
At last day came, and again his people cooked their meal.

sentences.original: namoya wîh-waniskâw aw oskinîkiw, misawâc namoya nk-âsamikawin, êy-itêyihtahk.
sentences.english: The young man would not get up, for he thought, “In any case I shall not be given food.”

sentences.original: piyisk ê-kîsi-mîcisowiht, â, ntawâsimisitik, wawêyîk! kipimipicihtânaw! êh-itwêt awa kisêyiniw, ê-wîh-kakwê-nôhtêsimât onahâhkisîma.
sentences.text: piyisk ê-kîsi-mîcisowiht ê-itwêt awa kisêyiniw ê-wî-kakwê-nôhtêsimât onahâhkisîma
sentences.english: At last, when his tentmates had finished their meal, “Now then, my children, make ready! We must not forget that we are moving camp!” said the old man, meaning to leave his son-in-law  behind.
The young man was not able to rise from where he lay.
Although they all made ready to go, that woman would not leave the tent.
“Get ready, Daughter! Now is when we move camp!” he told her.
The young wife wept, and listlessly went about making ready to go.
At last the young man dragged himself away from the camp.
His wife wept all the time, as her mats were being put on the sled.

sentences.original: êkwah êh-ati-sipwêhtêwiht, êkotah cîkih astâw mihtah, êh-astât aw oskinîkiskwêw, êh-pônahk, êkâ ta-kawacit! êh-itêyimât onâpêma.
sentences.text: êkwa ê-ati-sipwêhtêwiht êkota cîki astâw mihta ê-astât awa oskinîkiskwêw ê-pônahk ê-itêyimât onâpêma
sentences.english: Then, as the others proceeded to depart, she put sticks of firewood close by there, the young wife, and built a fire, for, “That he may not be cold!” was her thought concerning her husband.

sentences.original: êh-âta-sipwêhtêyit okâwiya, ayâw êkotah, êh-kisâtât onâpêma, tahk êh-mâtot.
sentences.text: ê-âta-sipwêhtêyit okâwiya ayâw êkota ê-kisâtât onâpêma tahki ê-mâtot
sentences.english: Although her mother had gone, she stayed there, close to her husband, weeping all the while.
For now her husband was barely alive.
At last the others stood still.

sentences.original: pê-sipwêhtêh! êh-itiht, âhci pikoh namoya tâpwêhtam.
sentences.english: “Come, be off!” she was bidden, but still she paid no heed.

sentences.original: kîtahtawêh ôhtâwiyah kâ-matwê-pîkiskwêyit, têpwâtihk anah! ta-pê-sipwêhtêw! êh-itikot.
sentences.english: Presently, there came the sound of her father's speech, “Call to that person! She is to be off and come!” he was saying of her.

sentences.original: âta ê-tâh-têpwâtiht, piyis ocêmêw onâpêma, nnâpêm, kisâkihitin; mâka kiwêh-nakatitn.
sentences.english: Although she was called again and again, at last she kissed her husband, and, “My husband, I love you; but I shall leave you.
Let me, too, die of hunger,” she said to him.
“My wife, you must try to live.
Go away from here.
Do not entertain such thoughts.

sentences.original: mâskôc pimâtisiyini, kîtahtawê wâpamatwâwi nôhtâwiy, kwayask t-âcimostawat, itêw,
sentences.english: Perhaps, if you live, someday, when you see my father and his people, you will be able to tell him the truth.
[You will suffer if you stay here.]

sentences.original: namoya misawâc nka-kîh-pimâtisin, âta kisâtamani, itêw.
sentences.english: In any event, I shall not be able to live, even if you stay with me,” he told her.
At last he persuaded her.
When they continued to call her, she went from there, weeping bitterly.
“Why, Daughter, what are you weeping about?
Stop your crying!” that old man bade his daughter;

sentences.original: namoy âna nânto kititâhkômâw, iyikohk kâ-mâtôyan, itêw.
sentences.english: “You are not in any way related to him, to be weeping like this,” he said to her.
So off she went, weeping.

sentences.original: kwah wiy âwa ê-pa-pimisihk aw oskinîkiw, êh-otâkosiniyik, kîtahtawê kêkway kâ-pêhtahk êh-pê-yôtiniyik.
sentences.text: êkwa wiya awa ê-pa-pimisihk awa oskinîkiw ê-otâkosiniyik kîtahtawê kêkway kâ-pêhtahk ê-pê-yôtiniyik
sentences.english: And as for that youth, as he lay there, toward evening, suddenly he heard something come, as with a gust of wind.

sentences.original: kîtahtawê kâ-pêhtahk êh-matwêwêyik, ê êh gay_gay_gay_gay! êh-pêy-itwêyit.
sentences.english: Suddenly he heard a shot, and, “Hey, hey, hi, hi, hi, hi!” someone came calling out.

sentences.original: êyakw êcik âni kê-nipahit! êyakonih êtokê opawâkanah awa kisêyiniw! itêyihtam.
sentences.english: “And so this is the one that is to kill me! Doubtless this is that old man's dream spirit!” he thought.

sentences.original: êkosi kiyipah mîna âsay kâ-pê-matwêwêyik, êh-pê-sâkowêyit.
sentences.text: êkosi kiyipa mîna âsay kâ-pê-matwêwêyik ê-pê-sâkowêyit
sentences.english: Then quickly again came the report of a shot, as that person came a-whooping.

sentences.original: mâka yôtiniyiw; ôtah ê-takohtêyit, iskotêw kwâskwêyâstitâyiwa, mistah êh-yôtinipayihtâyit.
sentences.text: mâka yôtiniyiw ôta ê-takohtêyit iskotêw kwâskwêyâstitâyiwa mistahi ê-yôtinipayihtâyit
sentences.english: But a wind blew; as that one arrived, he blew the flame into a leaping flare, striking it as with a gust of wind.

sentences.original: êyiwêhk êh-itâpit, akâm-iskotêw mihtih êh-astêyik, êkotah kîh-apiyiwa ayîsiyiniwa, miton êh-kawâhkatosoyit, wîstêpahkwayah êh-wiyâhtamiyit.
sentences.text: êyiwêhk ê-itâpit akâmiskotêw mihti ê-astêyik êkota kî-apiyiwa ayîsiyiniwa mitoni ê-kawâhkatosoyit wîstêpahkwaya ê-wiyâhtamiyit
sentences.english: When the youth at last looked, across the fire, where lay a log of firewood, there sat a man, very lean and clad in bits of smoky leather.
As he looked upon him, the other did not move his eyes from him.

sentences.original: êkwah êtok âw êkwah ê-wîh-nipahit! itêyihtam.
sentences.english: “Now, no doubt, now, is when he will kill me!” he thought.

sentences.original: kîtahtawê, hê hê hêy ha ha! itik;
sentences.english: Presently, “Alas, alas!” the other said to him;

sentences.original: tânis ôma wiya itah k-ôh-pa-pimisiniyin ? itik.
sentences.english: “Why are you lying here like this?” the other asked him.

sentences.original: hâ êy, nimanâcimâkan êh-wîh-nipahâhkatosôyit, êkos ôm êkwa êkâ âh-kîh-waskawiyân, êh-wîh-nipahâhkatosôyân, kâh-nakatikawiyân, itêw;
sentences.english: “Why, because my father-in-law means to kill me with starvation, therefore now, when I am unable to stir, because I am starved almost to death, I have been abandoned,” he told him;

sentences.original: âtah wiya êh-mâh-minahot, mâka êh-mahyakomit, namoya nikîh-nipahtân kêkway, êh-kisiwâhak, êh-mâh-mêtawêyân, itêw.
sentences.english: “Although he himself continues to kill game, yet, because he has cast a spell upon my luck, I cannot kill anything, because I have incurred his displeasure by continuing to play a game,” he told the other.

sentences.original: êhêh êy, ha ha, nôsisê! ât âni nîsta nikîh-kitimâkêyimâw, tâpw âna êh-kitimâkêyihtâkosit, mâka pêyak kêkway nikîh-mihtawamâw, oma kâ-tôtâsk âhcih.
sentences.english: “Alas, alas, my grandchild! The fact is, to be sure, that I have blessed him, for truly he was in a piteous state, but one thing I regret having given him, that with which he is doing this to you.
sentences.footnote: LB on {âhcih}:  {âhcih}: “from one place to another; continuing, in spite”; probably read {ohci}: “thence, therefore, by means of that.”

sentences.english: You will not die; even though, 'I shall die,' is your thought.
But you will go about with me.

sentences.original: pimiyah kik-ômîciwinânaw, êkotôwahk anih êh-omîciwiniyân, itik;
sentences.english: Fat will be our food, for such is my food,” the other told him;

sentences.original: êkwah, hâ, nôsisê, kakwê-waniskâh! simatapih! itik.
sentences.english: and then, “Come, Grandson, try to get up! Sit up!” the other told him.
At last he managed to raise himself.
“Grandson, try to rise to your feet!” the other told him.
He rose to his feet, holding fast to his gun and leaning on it to stand.
“Now, Grandson, watch out!” the other told him.
As the other bumped into him, he went right through him; over there, off to one side, the other was standing.
“There, my comrade!” the other was saying to him;
“Come rise from the ground!” he was saying to him;

sentences.original: k-êtwêcik ayîsiyiniwak, êkotôwah niya; mâka kîsta kika-pâkahkôwin.
sentences.english: “When mortal men say, 'Bony Spectre,' such am I; but you too shall be a bony spectre.
Your father-in-law shall not know that you live,” he told him.

sentences.original: êkos êh-at-ôhpipayihoyit, êh-ati-sâkôwêyit, wîstah, kâ-tôtamiyit owîcêwâkana, êkosi wîstah tôtam, êh-kîwêhtahikot.
sentences.text: êkosi ê-ati-ohpipayihoyit ê-ati-sâkôwêyit wîsta kâ-tôtamiyit owîcêwâkana êkosi wîsta tôtam ê-kîwêhtahikot
sentences.english: At that, when the other rose into the air and whooped as he went on his way, he too did as his companion had done, and the latter took him home.
Truly, they arrived at the other's dwelling.
Oh, at once he was given fat to eat.

sentences.original: êkotah ohci pâkahkosiwiw, pikw îtê wiyîhkohtôwihcih, âsay êy-asamihcik pimiy.
sentences.text: êkota ohci pâkahkosiwiw piko itê wiyîhkohtowihci âsay ê-asamihcik pimiy
sentences.english: Through these things he became a bony spectre, and, when a feast anywhere was given with thought of him, they were given fat to eat.

sentences.original: êkwah nâha kisêyiniw miywêyihtam, êh-nipahâhkatosot nnahâhkisîm, êy-itêyihtahk.
sentences.english: Then that old man off yonder rejoiced, thinking, “My son-in-law has starved to death.”

sentences.original: êkwah awa oskinîkiskwêw namoya mâna wîh-mîcisôw, êy-ât-âsamiht; piyis mâna tâpwêhtawâw ôhtâwiya, ê-kâ-kakwê-sîhkimikot.
sentences.text: êkwa awa oskinîkiskwêw namôya mâna wî-mîcisôw ê-ati-asamiht piyis mâna tâpwêhtawêw ôhtâwiya ê-kâ-kakwê-sîhkimikot
sentences.english: And that young woman was always unwilling to eat, when she was given food; but in the end she always obeyed her father, who kept urging her.

sentences.original: mistahi kwatakihtâw, pisisik êh-mâtot, êh-sâkihât onâpêma, tahkih êh-sîhkimiht, kwayask ta-mîcisot, mâka mayaw ohpimê k-êtohtêt, âsay êh-mâtot.
sentences.text: mistahi kwatakihtâw pisisik ê-mâtot ê-sâkihât onâpêma tahki ê-sîhkimiht kwayask ta-mîcisot mâka mayaw ohpimê kâ-itohtêt âsay ê-mâtot
sentences.english: She was very unhappy, weeping all the time, for love of her husband, as she was being constantly urged to eat well; but as soon as she could go off alone, already she was in tears.

sentences.original: kîtahtawê iyikohk êkwah ê-miyoskamiyik, kîwêpiciwak, itah omah kâ-mawacihitocik mâna, êkotê êy-ispicicik.
sentences.text: kîtahtawê iyikohk êkwa ê-miyoskamiyik kîwêpiciwak ita ôma kâ-mâwacîhitocik mâna êkotê ê-ispicicik
sentences.english: Presently, when the warm weather came, they moved their camp back whence they had come; to the place where they were in the habit of assembling, thither they moved their camp.

sentences.original: mahtih kiy-ây-iskwastamiyit oskanah paskwâw-iyiniw nk-âti-ntawâpamâw, itwêw awa kisêyiniw.
sentences.english: “Let me go see on the way whether they have left the Plains Cree's bones,” said the old man.

sentences.original: cîkâhtaw ê-wîh-pimipicicik, tâpwê otihtam ôm ômatokâhpiwâw.
sentences.text: cîkâhtaw ê-wî-pimipicicik tâpwê otihtam ôma omatokahpiwâw
sentences.english: As they were about to pass near the place in moving camp, he really did go to that abandoned camp-site of theirs.
When he looked, there were no bones lying about.
There was not even the gun.
So he went back where his family was camping for the night.

sentences.original: êh-takohtêt, yaw, nmwâc kêkway ay-iskwastamwak oskaniyiwa paskwâw-iyiniwa, itêw, npawâkanak!
sentences.english: When he arrived, “Yah, they have not left any bones at all from eating the Plainsman,” he told them, “those dream spirits of mine!

sentences.original: miton êsah wiyîhkipwâcik paskwâw-iyiniwa! itwêw, ê-mamâhtâkosit, nisâkôcihâw! êh-itêyimât.
sentences.english: It seems they much liked the taste of the Plains Cree!” he said, rejoicing as he thought of the other, “I have defeated him!”

sentences.original: êkos iyikohk itêh êh-takohtêcik êh-wîkiwiht, êkoyikohk kiskêyihtamwân êh-nipahâhkatosohât onahâhkisîma.
sentences.text: êkosi iyikohk itê ê-takohtêcik ê-wîkiwiht êkoyikohk kiskêyihtamwân ê-nipahâhkatosohât onahâhkisîma
sentences.english: So then, when they arrived where their people were camping, it was known of him that he had made his son-in-law starve to death.

sentences.original: êkos êh-âtah-kakwêcimiht, namoya kwayask âcimôwak; mâka kiskêyimâwak ê-macihtwâcik.
sentences.text: êkosi ê-âta-kakwêcimiht namôya kwayask âcimôwak mâka kiskêyimâwak ê-macihtwâcik
sentences.english: But, though he then was questioned, they did not tell the truth; but they were known to be sorcerers.

sentences.original: kîtahtawê aw oskinîkiskwêw êh-kakwêcimikot kîmôc iskwêwa, âcimôw, êh-nipahâhkatosohât paskwâw-iyiniwa.
sentences.text: kîtahtawê awa oskinîkiskwêw ê-kakwêcimikot kîmôc iskwêwa âcimôw
sentences.english: Presently, when the young woman was questioned in secret by the other women, she told the story: “Because he made the Plainsman starve to death.”

sentences.original: mistahi mihtâtêwak ôki sakâw-iyiniwak ôhi oskinîkiwa, osâm êh-miyosiyit, êkwah êh-kitimâkêyihtâkosiyit, ôhtâwiyiwa ê-kitimâkêyimikoyit.
sentences.text: mistahi mihtâtêwak ôki sakâw-iyiniwak ôhi oskinîkiwa osâm ê-miyosiyit êkwa ê-kitimâkêyihtâkosiyit ôhtâwîyiwa ê-kitimâkêyimikoyit
sentences.english: The Bush People grieved much for that young man, because he was handsome, and because he was lovable, even as his father had loved him.
But they feared that man; for he was a manitou person.
Then they stayed there.

sentences.original: kîtahtawê êh-nîpihk, êkwah awa oskinîkiw ôhtâwiya itohtêyiwa ôtah pêhonânihk, êkotah êh-wa-wîkiyit, êy-ihtatêyimikot, êkotah ta-takosihk omanâcimâkana.
sentences.text: kîtahtawê ê-nîpihk êkwa awa oskinîkiw ôhtâwiya itohtêyiwa ôta pêhonânihk êkota ê-wa-wîkiyit ê-ihtatêyimikot
sentences.english: Presently, when summer came, that young man's father came here to Battleford, and continued to camp here, thinking he was near: “Here he will come with his parents-in-law.”

sentences.original: mâka awa kisêyiniw namoya wîh-pê-nimitâsiw, êh-kostât paskwâw-iyiniwa otihtâwâwa.
sentences.text: mâka awa kisêyiniw namôya wî-pê-nimitâsiw ê-kostât paskwâw-iyiniwa otihtâwâwa
sentences.english: But that old man did not intend to come down to the open country, for he feared his son-in-law's father, the Plains Cree.
The other Bush Fellows came to the open country, coming to trade their furs at the post.
There they saw that Plains Cree.
He made inquiries as to where his son and his son's father-in-law were staying.

sentences.original: yâ, pakahkam namoya kataw tôtam sakâw-iyiniw; itêyimâw.
sentences.english: “Ho, surely that Bush Cree is doing something not right; that is what one thinks of him.
It is certain that you will never see your son.

sentences.original: pêyakwâw êsah êh-kîh-otihtâcik ayîsiyiniwah, namoya kîh-wâpamâw kikosis.
sentences.english: It seems that the one time when they came to where other people were, your son was not seen.

sentences.original: iyâtah-kakwêcimihci tântê tit-âyâyit, namoya kwayask wîh-âcimôw.
sentences.english: Although he was asked where he might be, he would not tell plainly.

sentences.original: kîtahtawê kîmôc kîh-kakwêcimik iskwêwa kistim, êkosi kiy-wîhtam êh-misi-wanâtisiyit onâpêma.
sentences.english: Then some women secretly asked your daughter-in-law, and she told that her husband had been done away with.

sentences.original: kêyâpic mistahi kwatakihtâw kistim, êkâ êh-wîcêwât onâpêma.
sentences.english: Your daughter-in-law is still very miserable because she has not her husband.”
Thus was the story told to the old man.
“If we could but see my daughter-in-law!” he said.

sentences.original: hâw, namoya anohc kâ-nîpihk ta-kîh-pêy-itohtêw, êh-kostahk ayisiyinînâhk tit-êtohtêt.
sentences.english: “Oh, he will not come this summer, for he is afraid to go among people.

sentences.original: êkosi mâna tôtam, kâh-misi-wanâcihâci oskinîkiwa, itâw aw okimâw.
sentences.english: That is the way he does whenever he has done away with a young man,” the chief was told.
He was unhappy because his son had been done away with.
So, at least, he had been told.

sentences.original: êkwah ôki êyokw âwa aw okimâw otihkwatimah êh-nîsiyit, mistahi mihtâtêwak wîscâsiwâwa ôk ôskinîkiwak.
sentences.text: êkwa ôki êwako awa awa okimâw otihkwatima ê-nîsiyit mistahi mihtâtêwak wîscâsiwâwa ôki oskinîkiwak
sentences.english: And those two nephews of the chief's, those youths grieved much for their cousin.

sentences.original: ômis îtwêwak : nôhtâh, mahtih nâtakâm itohtêtân.
sentences.english: hey spoke as follows: “Father, let us go up into the Bush Country.

sentences.original: kakwê-wâpamâtân ana kisêyiniw, mîna ta-kakwêh-pêhtamahk tântah nîscâs êh-pimisihk.
sentences.english: Let us try to see that old man, and let us try to hear where my cousin's body lies.

sentences.original: mâskôc namoya katawah ta-k-îsinâkwahk itah nîscâs wiyaw êh-astêyik, itêw ôhtâwiya;
sentences.english: Perhaps things do not look as is fitting, there where my cousin's body lies,” said one to his father;
“We have now enough goods.
Tell this to my uncle,” he said to his father;
“When now the people go to the open country, let him go along.

sentences.original: mâskôc ayiwakês ta-kaskêyihtam, papâ-nisikatisiyahkoh, itêw ôhtâwiya.
sentences.english: Surely, he would grieve even more, if we all went about alone in the wilderness,” he told his father.
Consenting, he told his brother-in-law what his sons had said.

sentences.original: êhag, itwêw awa okimâw, tâpwêh nanânis êy-ispiciwiht.
sentences.text: itwêw awa okimâw tâpwê nanânis ê-ispiciwiht
sentences.english: “Very well,” said the chief, and accordingly they moved their camps in different directions.

sentences.original: êkwah êh-takwâkiniyik, nâtakâm tohtêwak ôk ôskinîkiwak, ê-wîh-kakwê-wâpamâcik ôhi sakâw-iyiniwa.
sentences.text: êkwa ê-takwâkiniyik nâtakâm itohtêwak ôki oskinîkiwak ê-wî-kakwê-wâpamâcik ôhi sakâw-iyiniwa
sentences.english: So, when autumn came, those young men went northward to try and see that Bush Cree.
Accordingly, they moved their camp about, hunting on the way.

sentences.original: wiyâpamâtwâwi ayîsiyiniwah, kakwêcihkêmôwak tântê ta-pimisiniyit wîscâsiwâwa.
sentences.text: wiyâpamâtwâwi ayîsiyiniwa kakwêcihkêmôwak tânitê ta-pimisiniyit wîscâsiwâwa
sentences.english: Whenever they saw people, they inquired where their cousin's body lay.

sentences.original: êkosi namoya kiskêyihtamwân, mîn ôhi kisêyiniwa ê-wîh-kiskêyimâcik.
sentences.text: êkosi namôya kiskêyihtamwân mîna ôhi kisêyiniwa ê-wî-kiskêyimâcik
sentences.english: It was not known; nor was it known, when they desired to learn the whereabouts of that old man.

sentences.original: têpiyâhk an îskwêw wâpamâyahkoh, kêkway t-ôhtinamawâyahk, nîscâs owîkimâkana, êh-itwêcik ôk ôskinîkiwak, piyisk kapê-pipon papâ-ayâwak.
sentences.text: ê-itwêcik ôki oskinîkiwak piyisk kapê-pipon papâ-ayâwak
sentences.english: “At least, if we saw that woman, our cousin's wife, we might learn something from her,” said those youths, and thus stayed about, now here, now there, all winter long.
They did not succeed in learning the whereabouts of that old man.
At last the warm weather began to come on, and spring would soon be near.
Then at one time they were hunting.
“Father, we shall not be back today.

sentences.original: wâpahkih nka-takohtânân, ê-wîh-kakwê-wâpamak ayîsiyiniw nântaw, itwêw aw ôstêsimâw.
sentences.english: We shall come back tomorrow, for we want to see some people,” said the elder one.
Accordingly, they went hunting.
They took their blankets with them, for they were going to stay out all night.
Presently, as they walked along, they came upon the track of an elk.
They followed its trail.
Toward evening they came in sight of it.
Really, they killed it.

sentences.original: êkwah êkotah pânahikêwak, ê-wîh-kotawêcik, wâpahk îtâp ka-kîwânânaw, êh-itwêcik ôk ôskinîkiwak.
sentences.text: êkwa êkota pânahikêwak ê-wî-kotawêcik ê-itwêcik ôki oskinîkiwak
sentences.english: Right where they were, they cleared away the snow, to make a fire for “Tomorrow we shall go home,” said those youths.
When then they had built their fire and were making their roasts, night came on.

sentences.original: êkwah mistahi nikohtêwak, êkâ ta-kawacicik, êh-itêyihtahkik.
sentences.text: êkwa mistahi nikohtêwak êkâ ta-kawacicik ê-itêyihtahkik
sentences.english: Then they prepared a great amount of firewood, so as not to suffer from the cold.
So they sat there.
In due time they lay down; but they did not mean to sleep.
Presently they heard the report of a gun and someone coming a-whooping.
sentences.footnote: LB on {kâ-pêh-sâkôwêwiht}:  Probably read {kâ-pêh-sâkôwêyit}: “the other came a-whooping.”

sentences.original: yâ, nisîm, êkosi mâna itâcimâwak pâkahkosâk.
sentences.english: “Oho, Brother, this is what they tell of the bony spectres.
Such they must be,” said the elder.
So they lay there.

sentences.original: kîtahtawê kisiwâk mîna kâ-pê-matwêwêyik, âsay mîna ê-pê-sâkôwêyit.
sentences.text: kîtahtawê kisiwâk mîna kâ-pê-matwêwêyik âsay mîna ê-pê-sâkôwêyit
sentences.english: Presently again, from near by came the sound of a shot, and again someone's whooping.
Then they heard the coming of a rush of wind.

sentences.original: kwayask sêkisiw aw osîmimâw, êh-kostât pâkahkosah.
sentences.text: kwayask sêkisiw awa osîmimâw ê-kostât pâkahkosa
sentences.english: The younger was properly frightened, fearing the bony spectres.

sentences.original: ôtah êh-takoh-yôtinipayiyik, kâ-wâpamâcik akâm-iskotêw êh-apiyit pâkahkosah, kontah ê-wîh-pâhpiyit, mâ-mîskoc êh-kitâpamikocik.
sentences.text: ôta ê-tako-yôtinipayiyik kâ-wâpamâcik akâmiskotêw ê-apiyit pâkahkosa konita ê-wî-pâhpiyit mâ-mîskoc ê-kitâpamikocik
sentences.english: When the gust of wind reached them, there they saw, sitting at the far side of the fire, a bony spectre, smiling a hollow smile and looking now at one, now at the other.
The younger one grew frightened; he could not stir from the spot.

sentences.original: aw ostêsimâw, êyako tahkih kâh-kiyipa êh-kitâpamikot, kîtahtawê, miyâmay waskawîw, êh-itêyimât, âsay osîma êy-isikâtêsiniyit, kâ-nahapiyit pâkahkosah, ê-yâsipitâyit otâsiyânah aw ôskinîkiw, ê-wîh-sisikotiskênikot, aw ôstêsimâw k-ôtihtinât.
sentences.text: awa ostêsimâw êwako tahki kâh-kiyipa ê-kitâpamikot kîtahtawê ê-itêyimât âsay osîma ê-isikâtêsiniyit kâ-nahapiyit pâkahkosa ê-yâsipitâyit otâsiyâna awa oskinîkiw ê-wî-sisikotiskênikot awa ostêsimâw kâ-otihtinât
sentences.english: The elder, at whom the thing kept gazing every little while, suddenly thought, “Surely, he is about to make a move,” - and already at his younger brother's feet, as he lay, sat the bony spectre, and was drawing off the youth's breech-clout, to leap upon him by surprise; and the elder brother laid hold of the creature.
“Brother, get up! Let us give him a fight!

sentences.original: pisisik mâna k-âcimihcik êkos ê-wîh-tôtahkik, ôma kâ-wîh-tôtâsk! itêw osîma.
sentences.english: That which they are said always to be wanting to do, he is now about to do to you!” he told his brother.
sentences.footnote: LB:  I do not know what the bony spectres do, beyond wrestling.

sentences.original: yâh, awas, êyisiyiniwiyin! pakitinin! itêw pâkahkos.
sentences.english: “Faugh, go away, mortal man! Let go of me!” the bony spectre said to him.
“No! I am bound to try to take away your gun!” he told it.
The two attacked it and wrestled with it.
“I will not let you go!” he said to it, when he knew that he had it fast.
They both grappled with it and wrestled with it.
“Come, mortal man, do let me go!

sentences.original: ahpôh kika-wêhcihâwak pisiskiwak; kimiyitin, mitonih ta-minahoyan, itêw.
sentences.english: If you like, you may have easy play with game animals; I give you the gift of killing much game,” it told him.
“No! Such as you are given to cheating mortal men,” he told it.
“If you like, you shall have full length of life, you and your younger brother here.
Let me go!”
“No! I will not let you go!
“Take pity on my words! Let me go!

sentences.original: ahpôh kiwâhkômâkan mistah iyâhkosici, êtotikawiyini, kika-pimâcihâw, itik.
sentences.english: If you like, whenever your kinsman is sorely ill, and you are called to aid, you shall restore him to life,” it told him.
“No! Such as you are too much given to cheating mortal men.

sentences.original: pakitinitâni, namoya ta-kîh-ispayiw anima k-êsiyin, itêw.
sentences.english: If I let you go, that which you say to me will not come to pass,” he told it.
But by this time dawn was near.
The bony spectre knew that it would not be freed.

sentences.original: kîtahtawê kâh-miskonahk kêkway êh-pîmakâmêskamiyit ôhi pâkahkosah.
sentences.text: kîtahtawê kâ-miskonahk kêkway ê-pîmakâmêskamiyit ôhi pâkahkosa
sentences.english: Presently the one felt with his hand something which that bony spectre wore across its shoulder.
It was always holding fast to this object.

sentences.original: nisîm, kêkway awa mistahi kâ-sâkihtât, êh-pîmakâmêskahk.
sentences.english: “Brother, there is something to which this creature anxiously clings, something which is slung across its shoulder.
Let us try to get it away,” he told him.

sentences.original: yâh, êkâ wiya, êyîsiyiniwiyan! mistah ânima ê-sâkihtâyân!
sentences.english: “Oh, do not, mortal man! I prize it so highly!”
Suddenly that youth recognized it.

sentences.original: ayiwâk ihkin, nisîm! miyâmay ôma pakêsîwiyâkan, kîscâsinaw ôtôyâkan! itêw osîma.
sentences.english: “A wonder, Brother! Surely this is a bowl for the cup-game, our cousin's bowl!” he told his brother.

sentences.original: êkwah tâpwê, yâhâ, awasitik, êyîsiyiniwiyan! êkây ôtinamok! mistah ânima ê-sâkihtâyân!
sentences.english: So then, “Oho, be off, mortal man! Do not take it! I prize this thing too dearly!”
At last they got it away.
They recognized their cousin's gaming-bowl.
“Come, Brother, let us not lose hold of him!

sentences.original: iyây-îhkinokwêh, awa pâkahkos kâ-kanawêyihtahk kîscâsinawa opakêsêwiyâkan! itêwak.
sentences.english: What strange thing may it be, that this bony spectre is possessed of our cousin's gaming-bowl!” they said of it.
sentences.footnote: CHECK iyây (IC of heavy reduplication?) YUP and (VII) dubitative.

sentences.original: piyis êkwah êh-wâpaniyik, namoy êkwah wîh-waskawîw awa pâkahkos.
sentences.text: piyis êkwa ê-wâpaniyik namôya êkwa wî-waskawîw awa pâkahkos
sentences.english: When at last day broke, that bony spectre no longer tried to move.

sentences.original: êkwah wêwêkahpitêwak wâpowayânihk, nisîm, ka-kîwêhtahânaw, êh-itât osîma.
sentences.english: Then they wrapped it tightly in a blanket, and, “Brother, let us take him home with us,” said he to his younger brother.
They made ready to go.
By this time it was day.

sentences.original: êkwah awa ostêsimâw êh-nayômât pâkahkosah, êh-kîwêhtahâcik, piyis ê-wîh-takohtêcik, êkotah ayiwêpiwak.
sentences.text: êkwa awa ostêsimâw ê-nayômât pâkahkosa ê-kîwêhtahâcik piyis ê-wî-takohtêcik êkota ayiwêpiwak
sentences.english: Then the elder brother carried the bony spectre on his back, and they took it home with them, until, when they were almost at their destination, they halted.
“Now, Brother, go home.

sentences.original: wîhtamaw kôhtâwiyinaw : anima kâ-wîkiyahk kwêskâhtik ta-mânokêwak anima konta k-âstêk apâhkwâson; miton isi t-ânâskêwak maskosiyah; mîna mistahi kit-âstâwak mihtah.
sentences.english: Tell our father this: at the other side of the grove from where we camp, let them build a tipi with the tent-coverings of whatever kind they have; let them cover the ground well with grass; and let them place there a large supply of firewood.
Do not tell him that we are bringing this being,” he told him;
“If he asks you, do not tell him,” he told his brother;

sentences.original: êkwah anima mihkwêkin wêskwâhtêmihk kit-ânâskêwak; êkwah pêyak wâpowayân êkotah mîna t-âstâwak.
sentences.english: “And let them spread this red cloth on the ground opposite the entrance; and there let them lay also one blanket-robe.
When they have completed this, you will come and tell me;

sentences.original: mâka êkâ wiya ta-pê-itohtêwak kôhtâwiyinaw; êkâ wiya nka-kakwê-wâpamikwak, itêw.
sentences.english: but do not let our father and the others come here; they are not to try to see me,” he told him.
So the youth went home.
When he arrived, “Where is your elder brother?” his father asked him.
“Oh, quite near here he was stopping when I left him.

sentences.original: mâka ômis êh-itwêt : êh-itwêt, itêw ohtâwiya;
sentences.english: But this is what he says: 'At the far side of the grove from our camp they are to go and set up a tipi,' he says,” said he to his father;
“'When they have set up the tipi, they are to place there much grass, and they are to lay on the ground those things which we use as mats.
And opposite the entrance they are to use red cloth as a rug; and one blanket-robe they are to place there,' says my older brother,” said he to his father.

sentences.original: ê hê hê hê ha ha! itwêw awa kisêyiniw;
sentences.english: “Alas, alas!” cried the old man;
“It looks as though my son had come to some grief!” he cried.

sentences.original: namoya! itwêw aw osîmimâw; kiyâm kakwêyahok, itêw ôhtâwiya.
sentences.english: “No!” said the younger brother; “Try to do the work quickly,” he told his father.

sentences.original: tâpwê wawêyîwak, êh-nitawi-mânokêcik ôk îskwêwak, awa kisêyiniw maskosiyah êh-manisahk, ê-wîh-anâskêcik.
sentences.text: tâpwê wawêyîwak ê-nitawi-mânokêcik ôki iskwêwak awa kisêyiniw maskosiya ê-manisahk ê-wî-anâskêcik
sentences.english: Accordingly they made ready, the women going and setting up the tent, and the old man mowing grass to use on the floor.
Quickly they finished it.
“There, it is ready, my son!” he told him.

sentences.original: â, nôhtâh, kiyawâw kahkiyaw êkâ wiyah pêy-itohtêk; mîna êkâ wiya kakwê-pêy-itâpik, itâw.
sentences.english: “Now, Father, all of you, do not come there; and do not try to look,” he told him.

sentences.original: êkosi êh-ntawi-wîhtamawât ostêsah, êkosi kîwâhtahêw awa pâkâhkosah;
sentences.text: êkosi ê-nitawi-wîhtamawât ostêsa êkosi kîwêhtahêw awa pâkahkosa
sentences.english: Then he went and told his elder brother, and he brought home the bony spectre;

sentences.original: pîhtokahêw, wîkiwâhk êh-ahât, ôm îtah mihkwêkin k-ânâskêwiht.
sentences.text: pîhtokahêw wîkiwâhk ê-ahât ôma ita mihkwêkin kâ-anâskêwiht
sentences.english: he brought it into their tent and laid it there where the red cloth had been placed as a rug for him.

sentences.original: êkosi pa-pimisin awa pâkahkos, êh-akwanahiht, êkwah êh-nâtahk ta-mîcicik aw ôskinîkiw.
sentences.text: êkosi pa-pimisin awa pâkahkos ê-akwanahiht êkwa ê-nâtahk ta-mîcicik awa oskinîkiw
sentences.english: So there lay the bony spectre, covered with a rug, while the youth went to get something for them to eat.
At last night fell.

sentences.original: kîtahtawê êkwah ê-wîh-wâpaniyik, nisîm, mahti nâtah pimih, itêw, êkwah wiyâkan, êkwah askihk.
sentences.english: Then, towards dawn, “Brother, go fetch some fat,” he told him, “and a bowl, and a kettle.”
He fetched them.

sentences.original: êkwah êwako êh-pêtât, êh-tihkisahk oma pimiy, êkosi wiyâkanihk sîkinam, êh-tahkikamastât êywako.
sentences.text: êkwa êwako ê-pêtât ê-tihkisahk ôma pimiy êkosi wiyâkanihk sîkinam ê-tahkikamastât êwako
sentences.english: When he had brought them, he melted the fat and poured it into the bowl, and set it to cool.
“Here, Bony Spectre, drink this!
You are fond of fat, they always say of the like of you,” he said to it.
It would not take it.

sentences.original: piyis waniskânêw, êkwah otôniyihk êh-akonahk oma wiyâkan, minihkwêh! êh-itât.
sentences.text: piyis waniskânêw êkwa otôniyihk ê-akonahk ôma wiyâkan ê-itât
sentences.english: At last he raised it from where it lay and held the bowl to its lips, and said to it, “Drink!”
At last it really did drink.
When he thought, “Now it has drunk much,” he stopped giving it to drink.
Once more he gave it drink.
It drank all.

sentences.original: kîtahtawê êh-mêkw-âpit awa pâkahkos, kâ-pwah-pwâkompayit pisisik êh-kaskitêwâkamiyik.
sentences.text: kîtahtawê ê-mêkwâ-apit awa pâkahkos kâ-pwa-pwâkomipayit pisisik ê-kaskitêwâkamiyik
sentences.english: Then soon, as the bony spectre sat there, it vomited, bringing up nothing but a black liquid.

sentences.original: nisîm, mahti mîna pêyakwâw nâtah pimiy, itêw.
sentences.english: “Brother, once more, fetch some fat,” he told him.

sentences.original: âsay mîna pêtâw, mîn êyako êh-tihkisahk; êh-minahât, âsay mîna pwâkomoyiwa.
sentences.text: âsay mîna pêtâw mîna êwako ê-tihkisahk ê-minahât âsay mîna pwâkomoyiwa
sentences.english: Again he brought some, and this too he melted, and gave the creature to drink, and again it vomited.
This time very green was that which it threw up.
Again he gave it to drink.
This time, something bright yellow.
Then he left it alone, and it lay down  again.

sentences.original: kîtahtawê êh-otâkosiniyik, ômisi k-êtwêt awa pâkahkos : nîscâs, mahti pêyakwâw minahin pimiy; miyâmay kiwîh-pimâcihin, k-êtwêt awa pâkahkos.
sentences.text: kîtahtawê ê-otâkosiniyik ômisi kâ-itwêt awa pâkahkos kâ-itwêt awa pâkahkos
sentences.english: Presently, toward evening, thus spoke that bony spectre: “Cousin, pray once more give me fat to drink; for it is plain that you mean to restore me to life,” said that bony spectre.
“Come, Brother, once more fetch some fat.
Do not tell our father,” he told him.

sentences.original: tâpwê pêtâw pimih, êwako mîna êh-tihkisahk, êh-minahât mîna.
sentences.text: tâpwê pêtâw pimiy êwako mîna ê-tihkisahk ê-minahât mîna
sentences.english: Accordingly, he brought fat, and this, too, they melted, and gave to that person to drink.
He drank it all, and vomited again.
This time, white was that which he throw up.
When he had done vomiting, “Cousin, now I am fully conscious.

sentences.original: niy ôma, nîscâs, ê-papâ-pâkahkôwiyân! itêw wîscâsah.
sentences.english: It is I, my cousin, who have been going about in the form of a bony spectre!” he told his cousin.
He was none other than that handsome youth who had starved to death.

sentences.original: êkosi êkwah awa osîma, hâ, nsîm, tahtoh k-âyât kôhtâwiyinaw maskihkiyah ta-pakâhtâwak, itêw osîma;
sentences.text: êkosi êkwa awa osîma itêw osîma
sentences.english: Then said the one to his brother, “Come, Brother, let them set to boil as many medicinal herbs as our father has.
Do you tell him this.

sentences.original: mistah ôma êh-wîh-miywêyihtamahk, pimâcihâyahkoh kîscâsinaw, itêw.
sentences.english: Greatly now we shall rejoice, if we restore our cousin to life,” he said to him.
So he went to make the request of his father.
Accordingly, the old man set the medicines to boil.

sentences.original: êh-kîsihtât, êyak ôm ôhci mîna êh-minahâcik oscâsiwâwa, êkosi tâpwê pimâtisiyiwa.
sentences.text: ê-kîsihtât êwako ôma ohci mîna ê-minahâcik wîscâsiwâwa êkosi tâpwê pimâtisiyiwa
sentences.english: When he had finished this, again, they gave to their cousin to drink, and now truly he lived.
sentences.footnote: LB on {oscâsiwâwa}:  The normal form is {wîstsâsiwâwa}, but cf., a few lines below, {ostâsah} for {wîstâsah}; perhaps a neologism.

sentences.english: Then they gave him food, and they, too, ate.
“Cousin, truly, I am glad to live and look upon all of you!
Whatever you say I will do, for you have restored me to life.”

sentences.original: â, namoya, niscâs! kiya nawac pikw êh-itwêyan nka-tôtênân.
sentences.english: “Oh, no, Cousin! Rather, whatever you say, we others will do.

sentences.original: nama wîhkâc kêkway ka-nâtên, itêw oscâsah.
sentences.english: Never shall you go for anything,” he told his cousin.

sentences.original: êyikohk êh-miyôskawiyit, êkwah, nîscas, êkwah cî kâ-wâpamikwak nôhtâwiy nikâwiy mîna nimis ? itwêyiwa.
sentences.english: Then, when he was quite well, “Cousin, may my father and mother and sister see you now?” he asked.
“Yes, let them come and see me.”
Then they went to tell them.
“Father, 'What are these persons trying to do?' you are thinking.

sentences.original: ôma kâ-mâciyâhk pâkahkos ê-kiy-ôtihtikoyâhk, êyakô ê-pê-kîwêhtahâyâhk;
sentences.english: That time when we were hunting, a bony spectre came where we were, and we brought it home here with us;
because the bony spectre had our cousin's gaming-bowl, we brought it home with us.

sentences.original: êyakw âna êh-mâh-minahiht pimiy, iyikohk êh-âpahkawisit, êkwah maskihkiyah kâ-pakâhtâyan, êkwanih mîna êh-mâh-minahâyâhk.
sentences.english: Then, when it was given repeated drinks of fat, when he came to himself, that was when you set medicines to boil, and these, too, we gave him to drink.

sentences.original: êkosi êkwah, êh-itikoyêk, êwakw ês âna,, kâ-kih-itiht nîscâs, ês âna êh-pâkahkôwit.
sentences.english: And so now, 'They may come and see me,' he says to you, for he turns out to be none other than that cousin of mine, of whom it was said, 'He has been destroyed;' it appears that he has been in the form of a bony spectre.

sentences.original: mâk êkwah kâw êkwah âpisisin, itêw.
sentences.english: But now he has come back to his natural state,” he told him.

sentences.original: êkosi êkw êh-ati-wayawît, ôk ôk êh-itohtêcik, tâpwê wâpamêwak.
sentences.text: êkosi êkwa ê-ati-wayawît ôki ôki ê-itohtêcik tâpwê wâpamêwak
sentences.english: Then, as he left the tent, these people went there and really, they saw him.
They recognized him, and welcomed him.
So there they all stayed.

sentences.original: kîtahtawê mâna, nîscâs, ôtah kisiwâk ayâwak môswak. ntawi-nipah, êh-itwêt awa kâ-kîh-pâkahkôwit, êkos êh-ntawi-nipahâcik ôhi, piyis kiyipah tâhcipôw.
sentences.text: kîtahtawê mâna ê-itwêt awa kâ-kî-pâkahkôwit êkosi ê-nitawi-nipahâcik ôhi piyis kiyipa tâhcipôw
sentences.english: Often, in the time that followed, “Cousin, some moose are close by. Go kill one,” he would say who had been a bony spectre, and they would go kill one, and so finally, he soon recovered his flesh with good fare.

sentences.original: êkosi êkwah pê-sipwêhtêwak, êkwah ê-kîwêhtahâcik wîscâsiwâwa.
sentences.text: êkosi êkwa pê-sipwêhtêwak êkwa ê-kîwêhtahâcik wîscâsiwâwa
sentences.english: So then they set out to come here, to bring their cousin home.
At last, in spring, they arrived here at Battleford.

sentences.original: namoya itah êh-wîkiwiht wîh-kapêsiwak, êkâ ta-wâpamimiht ôhi, mîna êkâ ta-pêhtahk nâha kisêyiniw kâ-kîh-nipahâhkatosohât.
sentences.text: namôya ita ê-wîkiwiht wî-kapêsiwak êkâ ta-wâpamimiht ôhi mîna êkâ ta-pêhtahk nâha kisêyiniw kâ-kî-nipahâhkatosohât
sentences.english: They did not care to camp where the people were staying, lest he be seen, and lest the old man hear of it who had starved him.
For this reason they kept their cousin concealed.
At last they moved their camp and brought it here.
Their uncle was not there.

sentences.original: kâwih kâ-kîsih-miyosit aw oskinîkiw, êkos îsi miyosiw.
sentences.text: kâwi kâ-kîsi-miyosit awa oskinîkiw êkosi isi miyosiw
sentences.english: That youth was now again as handsome as he had formerly been.
Then, as they came trekking into the open country, presently they came in sight of people.

sentences.original: êh-kakwêcihkêmocik, osisiwâwa namoya wâhyaw âcimimâwa êh-wîkiyit.
sentences.text: ê-kakwêcihkêmocik osisiwâwa namôya wâhyaw âcimimâwa ê-wîkiyit
sentences.english: When they asked, their uncle was said to be camping not far from there.
The older brother rode there, to see his uncle.
He saw him.
His aunt wept, remembering her son.
“Do not weep, my aunt,” he said to her.

sentences.original: êkosi mîk osisah miskotâkay êh-mîkisiwiyik, sihkosiwayânah êh-kikamoyit, mîna mitâsah.
sentences.text: êkosi miyik osisa miskotâkay ê-mîkisiwiyik sihkosiwayâna ê-kikamoyit mîna mitâsa
sentences.english: Then his uncle gave him a beaded jacket with weaselskin tassels, and breeches.
He took only the breeches.

sentences.original: oma wiya miskotâkay nântaw ka-kîh-itâpacihtân, itêw osisah, nîscâs tit-ôskotâkât, êh-itêyihtahk;
sentences.english: “As for this jacket, you will have use for it,” he told his uncle, and his thought was, “My cousin shall have it.” --

sentences.original: hâ, nisisê, kisiwâk ôm ôtah niwîkinân.
sentences.english: “Now, uncle, we are camping close by here.
I have come to invite you to move your camp there tomorrow,” he told him.
He did not tell him that his cousin was alive.
Thereupon he rode back.
He arrived at nightfall.
He told his cousin what he had done.
“I have seen your father and his people.
Tomorrow they will move their camp here,” he told him;
“I did not tell them that you are alive,” he told him.
Then really, the next day, the others came with their camp.
They encamped close by.
They wept when they saw them.

sentences.original: yâ, nicâhkos, kâya mâtok! itêw ocâhkosah.
sentences.english: “Oh, Sister-in-Law, do not weep!” said the woman to her sister-in-law.
They ceased lamenting.

sentences.original: êkwah wiskwâhtêmihk pimisin aw oskinîkiw, êh-wêwêkisihk.
sentences.text: êkwa wêskwâhtêmihk pimisin awa oskinîkiw ê-wêwêkisihk
sentences.english: Opposite the entranceway lay that youth, wrapped in a covering.

sentences.original: hâw, ôtah ta-pê-pîhtokêw nisis êkwah nisikos, itêw.
sentences.english: “Now then, my uncle and aunt are to come inside here,” he told them.
They entered and stood at the foot-end of their son's couch.
“Uncle, what would you think, if you saw my cousin?”
He bowed his head.

sentences.original: nitihkwâh, nkah-miywêyihtên, kîscâs wâpamak itah êh-pimisihk, itwêw aw okimâw.
sentences.english: “Nephew, I should be glad to see the place where your cousin lies,” said that chief.
“Come, Cousin, arise!” he bade him.

sentences.original: êh-waniskâyit, awîn ôhi, êyakoni okosisah wâwiyak!
sentences.text: ê-waniskâyit awîna ôhi êwakoni okosisa wâwiyak
sentences.english: When he arose, who was it but, incredibly, his son!

sentences.original: kêkâc kipatâhtam awa kisêyiniw, iyikohk êh-miywêyihtahk, êh-wâpamât okosisah.
sentences.text: kêkâc kipatâhtam awa kisêyiniw iyikohk ê-miywêyihtahk ê-wâpamât okosisa
sentences.english: The old man almost choked with emotion, so happy was he, when he beheld his son.
So they rejoiced greatly.
Then, on the next day, they moved their camp to Battleford.

sentences.original: mâka namoya wîhtamwak êh-pimâtisiyit ôh ôskinîkiwa, êh-kostâcik nêhi kisêyiniwa, mâskôc pêhtahkih, mîna nka-misi-wanâcihikonân, êy-itêyihtahkik.
sentences.text: mâka namôya wîhtamwak ê-pimâtisiyit ôhi oskinîkiwa ê-kostâcik nêhi kisêyiniwa ê-itêyihtahkik
sentences.english: But they did not make it known that that youth was alive, for they feared yonder old man, thinking, “Perhaps, if he hears this, he will destroy us all.”
So they pitched camp.

sentences.original: êh-wâpahk, sakaw-iyinîsak kâ-pâpicicik, awîn ôhi, êkwah k-âyâyit ôhih kâh-kî-nipahâhkatosôhikot, êkwah ê-wîh-mâhiskamiyit.
sentences.text: ê-wâpahk sakâw-iyinîsak kâ-pâpicicik awîna ôhi êkwa kâ-ayâyit ôhi kâ-kî-nipahâhkatosohikot êkwa ê-wî-mâhiskamiyit
sentences.english: The next day some Bush Folk came camping there, and, behold, among them was the one who had starved him, coming to trade at the post.

sentences.original: nîscâs, mahtih ntawâpahkêk, mahti kê-wâpamâyêk niwîkimâkan, itêw.
sentences.english: “Cousin, pray, go look if you can see my wife,” he told them.
So those young men went there.

sentences.original: nawac kiyipah kâ-pê-pîhtokêyit ôhih sakâw-iyiniwa, wâpamikwak wîscâsiwâwa ôwikimâkaniyiwa.
sentences.text: nawac kiyipa kâ-pê-pîhtokêyit ôhi sakâw-iyiniwa wâpamikwak wîscâsiwâwa owîkimâkaniyiwa
sentences.english: That Bush Cree had come and entered before them, and their cousin's wife saw them.

sentences.original: kêyâpic namwâc wawêsiyiwa, kêyâpic ê-mihtâtât aw owîkimâkana, nîso-pipon aspin kâ-nipahâhkatosoyit, k-êtêyihtahk, owîkimâkana.
sentences.text: kêyâpic namwâc wawêsiyiwa kêyâpic ê-mihtâtât awa owîkimâkana nîso-pipon aspin kâ-nipahâhkatosoyit kâ-itêyihtahk owîkimâkana
sentences.english: Even now she had not put on any ornaments, for she was still grieving for her husband, who had, so far as she knew, starved to death two  years before.

sentences.original: mayaw êh-wâpamât ôh ôskinîkiwa, sêmâk tapahtiskwêyiw aw oskinîkiskwêw, êh-pahpahkikawâpit, owîkimâkana wîscâsiyiwa êh-nisitawêyimât.
sentences.text: mayaw ê-wâpamât ôhi oskinîkiwa sêmâk tapahtiskwêyiw awa oskinîkiskwêw ê-pahpahkikawâpit owîkimâkana wîscâsiyiwa ê-nisitawêyimât
sentences.english: As soon as she saw those youths, the young woman bowed her head and wept, because she recognized her husband's cousins.

sentences.original: êkwah awa kisêyiniw, ê hê hê hêy ha ha! itwêw;
sentences.english: And that old man cried, “Dear me, dear me!

sentences.original: itah oka-kîh-miywêyihtêh ninahâhkisîm, wîscâsah kîh-wâpamât, êkâ katawah kâ-kîh-ay-ispayiyâhk! itwêw awa kisêyiniw.
sentences.english: How happy my son-in-law would have been to see his cousins, unlucky as we have been!” said that old man.
