sentences.original: êkosi kiyipa ati-wayawîwak ôk ôskinîkiwak, wîscâsiwâwa ê-wih-âcimostawâcik.
sentences.text: êkosi kiyipa ati-wayawîwak ôki oskinîkiwak wîscâsiwâwa ê-wî-âcimostawâcik
sentences.english: At that those youths quickly went out, to go tell their cousin.
“Cousin, we have seen our kinswoman.
sentences.footnote: LB on {ntawêmânân}:  {nitawêmâw}: “my sister (man speaking); my brother (woman speaking)” is widely used between persons of the opposite sex; whether the use here, in the sense of “my cross-cousin's wife (man speaking)” is specialized or not, I cannot say.

sentences.english: Even now she wears no finery.
It seems that truly she has been grieving for you.
As soon as she recognized us, she shed tears,” he told him.

sentences.original: iyikohk êh-pimi-kîwêyit, êkwah k-êtohtêt awa nôtokêsiw, ostimah êh-ntawâpamât, ntawi-ntom, êh-itât aw oskinîkiw okâwiya.
sentences.text: iyikohk ê-pimi-kîwêyit êkwa kâ-itohtêt awa nôtokêsiw ostima ê-nitawi-wâpamât ê-itât awa oskinîkiw okâwiya
sentences.english: As soon as they went on home, that old woman went there to visit her daughter-in-law, for, “Go see her,” that youth had said to his mother.
She went there.

sentences.original: êh-pîhtokêt, hêy hêy hêy hi hi! itwêw awa kisêyiniw.
sentences.english: When she entered, “Dear me, dear me!” cried that old man.
The young woman wept, when she saw her mother-in-law.

sentences.original: awa wiya kisêyiniw, êhêhêy hi hi! k-êtwêt;
sentences.english: But the old man cried, “Dear me, dear me!

sentences.original: oka-kih-miywêyihtêh ninahâhkisîm, itah ta-kîh-wâpamât okâwiya ôhtâwiya, iyikohk kâ-kîh-kîsinâcihikowisiyâhk, êh-misi-wanâtisit ninahâhkisîm, itwêw.
sentences.english: How glad my son-in-law would have been, to see here his mother and his father, cruelly deprived as we have been by powers above our control, in my son-in-law's destruction!” he said.

sentences.original: namoya êh-kiskêyihtahk êh-pimâtisiyit awa k-êtwêt kisêyiniw.
sentences.text: namôya ê-kiskêyihtahk ê-pimâtisiyit awa kâ-itwêt kisêyiniw
sentences.english: The old man said this not knowing that the other lived.
Then night came.

sentences.original: êh-pê-ntomak awa nistim, ê-wîh-wâpamikot osisah, itêw.
sentences.english: “I have come to invite my daughter-in-law here, for her father-in-law wishes to see her,” she told them.

sentences.original: hâ, nyâ, nitânis! wiyâyipac kinôhtê-wâpamik ntihtâwâw! itêw.
sentences.english: “There, go, Daughter! It is gratifying that my fellow-father-in-law wishes to see you!” he said to her.
She went home with her.

sentences.original: wâhyawês êy-ihtâcik, nisikosê, kont âniki kâ-mihtâtâmôwi-kîskwêcik, kikosisah wiyawâw aniki ê-misi-wanâcihâcik.
sentences.english: When they had gone a ways, “Mother-in-Law, it is but in pretense that those people carry on as though they were grieving, for it is they who destroyed your son.

sentences.original: ahpôh ôma wâh-mâtôyânih, nôhcihikwak, itwêw aw oskinîkiskwêw.
sentences.english: Even when I would weep, they stop me,” said the young woman.

sentences.original: â, nistim, êkâ wiya âtota kiyâm! itêw.
sentences.english: “Oh, Daughter-in-Law, please, do not speak of that!” she told her.
So they entered their dwelling.
When she greeted her father-in-law, she wept.
“Be quiet, Daughter-in-Law.
Do not weep,” he told her.
Then, when she had eaten, “Go home now, my daughter-in-law.
It is getting very dark,” she told her.
So she went out of the tent.
There that young man was lying in wait for her.

sentences.original: êyakô ohci k-ôh-itât awa nôtokêsiw, êkos ê-kîh-itikot okosisah.
sentences.text: êwako ohci kâ-ôh-itât awa nôtokêsiw êkosi ê-kî-itikot okosisa
sentences.english: That was why the old woman had said this to her, for her son had bidden her so.

sentences.original: êkwah awa oskinîkiw itah êh-pimisihk, êh-pimohtêyit, pasikôw, êh-miciminât.
sentences.text: êkwa awa oskinîkiw ita ê-pimisihk ê-pimohtêyit pasikôw ê-miciminât
sentences.english: Then, where the young man lay, as she walked by, he arose and seized hold of her.
“Do let me go!

sentences.original: aspin niwîkimâkan kâ-misi-wanâtisit, namoya wîhkâc êkosi nitêyihtên, kotak nâpêw ta-ntawêyimak, itêw.
sentences.english: Ever since my husband came to grief, I have never had the feeling of wishing for another man,” she said to him.
“Oh, I shall not let you go!
It is I, my wife!  I am alive!

sentences.original: êyakw ânima itah kâ-kîh-nakasiyêk, êkos ânima nikîh-pê-sa-sipwêhtân, itêw.
sentences.english: From that place where you left me behind, I have come here,” he told her.
She did not believe him.

sentences.original: êkwah nôhtâwiy wîkiwâhk tohtêtân pitah, k-ôh-pê-wayawiyan, itêw.
sentences.english: “Then let us but go to my father's dwelling, from which you have even now come,” he told her.
She paid no heed to this.
“Look, here is my bowl for the cup-game!” he said to her.

sentences.original: êkoyikohk tâpwêhtam aw oskinîkiskwêw, kontah êh-mâtot, êh-oy-ocêmât onâpêma, êkw êh-kîwêhtahikot.
sentences.text: êkoyikohk tâpwêhtam awa oskinîkiskwêw konita ê-mâtot ê-oy-ocêmât onâpêma êkwa ê-kîwêhtahikot
sentences.english: Then the young woman believed it, and wept without grief, kissing her husband again and again, as he took her back to his dwelling.

sentences.original: êh-pîhtokêcik êkwah, tâpwê miton nisitawêyimêw onâpêma.
sentences.text: ê-pîhtokêcik êkwa tâpwê mitoni nisitawêyimêw onâpêma
sentences.english: When now they entered, she did indeed fully recognize her husband.
So there they stayed then.

sentences.original: iyikohk êh-wâpaniyik, ka-kaskikwâsôw, êh-miyât aw iskwêw ostima t-ôtayôwinisiyit.
sentences.text: iyikohk ê-wâpaniyik ka-kaskikwâsôw ê-miyât awa iskwêw ostima ta-otayôwinisiyit
sentences.english: The next day she spent at sewing, for that woman gave her daughter-in-law things to wear.
At noon, her elder sister came to get her.
The youth hid himself.
His sister-in-law did not see him.
His wife kept on sewing.
“You are to come home now!” she told her.
“My daughter-in-law is first to sew her garments.
When she has finished sewing them, she will come home,” she told her.

sentences.original: iyikohk êh-tipiskâyik, êkwah kîwêw aw ôskinîkiskwêw.
sentences.text: iyikohk ê-tipiskâyik êkwa kîwêw awa oskinîkiskwêw
sentences.english: When darkness was failing, then the young woman went home.
Her husband went with her.

sentences.original: êh-pîhtokêt aw iskwêw, nâwayês kâ-pîhtokêyit onâpêma.
sentences.text: ê-pîhtokêt awa iskwêw nâwayês kâ-pîhtokêyit onâpêma
sentences.english: When she entered the tipi, her husband went in behind her.
The old man was frightened.
“My son-in-law, please let me live!” he said to him.

sentences.original: yâ, nimanâcimâkan, namoya nântaw kitêyimitn, ê-kîh-âtah-tôtawiyan;
sentences.english: “Oh, my father-in-law, I bear you no grudge at all, even though you did that to me;
I do not think anything of it!”

sentences.original: tahto kêkway êh-miywâsiniyik ê-kîh-atâwêt awa kisêyiniw, kahkiyaw miyêw onahâhkisîma, mîn êh-iskonât atâwâkanah, nikikwayâna, pahkêkinwa, êh-miyât.
sentences.text: tahto kêkway ê-miywâsiniyik ê-kî-atâwêt awa kisêyiniw kahkiyaw miyêw onahâhkisîma mîna ê-iskonât atâwâkana nikikwayâna pahkêkinwa ê-miyât
sentences.english: As many fine things as that old man had bought at the trading-post, all of them he gave to his son-in-law, as well as the furs which he had kept out for himself; otterskins, and cured buffalo hides he gave him.
“Pray let me live, my son-in-law!” he said to him.

sentences.original: êkosi namoya nântaw nitêyihtên, itwêw aw oskinîkiw.
sentences.english: “I tell you, I think nothing at all of it,” the youth answered him.

sentences.original: êkos êh-ati-pasikôt, êh-kîwêcik owîkimâkana, ocayânisiwâwa êh-kîwêhtatâcik, mistahi mâkwêyimôw awa kisêyiniw, onahâhkisîma ê-nisitawêyimât.
sentences.text: êkosi ê-ati-pasikôt ê-kîwêcik owîkimâkana ocayânisiwâwa ê-kîwêhtatâcik mistahi mâkwêyimôw awa kisêyiniw onahâhkisîma ê-nisitawêyimât
sentences.english: Then he rose to his feet, and he and his wife went home, taking their belongings with them;  and greatly worried was that old man, having recognized his son-in-law.

sentences.original: êkwah êh-kawisimocik, niwîkimâkan, itwêw aw oskinîkiw, tânisi, kimiywêyihtên cî êh-oyôhtâwiyin ?
sentences.english: Then, as they went to bed, “My wife,” said that young man, “Tell me, are you glad that you have a father?”

sentences.original: namoya! nikisiwâhik ana, mâna êh-kîh-kitimahisk, êh-kîh-kakwâtakihisk.
sentences.english: “No! He made me hate him, when he made you miserable and tormented you.
I am far more glad that I can lay eyes upon you,” she told him.

sentences.original: hâw, tân âna mîna êkos îsi nôcihtât tâpiskôc kôhtâwiy ? itêw.
sentences.english: “Now, which ones have followed the same ends as your father?” he asked her.

sentences.original: nikâwiy ana wiya miyo-pimâtisiw, êkwah ana k-âskôwiskawak.
sentences.english: “As for my mother, she is a good person, and so is the sister to whom I am next in age.

sentences.original: nimis wiy âna omisimâw, k-êtâtisit nôhtâwiy, êkos îtâtisiw, itêw.
sentences.english: But as for my oldest sister, she is of the same character as my father,” she told him.
“I see!”

sentences.original: êkos ômis îtêyihtam awa oskinîkiw : hâw, anohc oma kâ-wêh-nipât, kayahtê namoya ta-kih-waskawîw;
sentences.english: Then that youth thought, “Now, tonight when he sleeps, let him suddenly lose the power of moving his limbs;
let that old man be paralyzed!
And let him lose the power of speech!
Until autumn comes, let him be unable to stir a limb!

sentences.original: êkosi êkotah mîna kiyipa otânisa ka-pwâna-waskawiyiwa, anihih omisimâwa! itêyihtam, êkwah êh-kawisimot.
sentences.english: And also let his daughter soon lose the power of movement, that eldest one!” he thought, and lay down to sleep.

sentences.original: kîtahtawê êh-wâpaniyik, namoya waskawîw ana kisêyiniw, êh-nipôwisit.
sentences.text: kîtahtawê ê-wâpaniyik namôya waskawîw ana kisêyiniw ê-nipôwisit
sentences.english: Then, in the morning, that old man could not stir, and was paralyzed.
Also, he could not speak.
That young woman was sent for.
“Come, see our father!
What can be the matter with him?

sentences.original: kayahtê nipôwisiw; namoya mîna pîkiskwêw, pêy-itêw awa osîma.
sentences.english: Suddenly he has become paralyzed; and he does not speak,” one came and told her sister.
“I do not care to go and see him,” she told her elder sister.

sentences.original: iyikohk aw oskinîkiw, mahtih ntawâpamâtân kôhtâwiy, itêw.
sentences.english: But the young man, in turn, said to her, “Let us go see your father.”
So they went there.

sentences.original: êh-pîhtokêt, mayaw êh-nsitawêyimât awa kisêyiniw onahâhkisîma, kontah êh-cîpotonêyit, nik-atamiskawâw, êh-itêyimât onahâhkisîma.
sentences.text: ê-pîhtokêt mayaw ê-nisitawêyimât awa kisêyiniw onahâhkisîma konita ê-cîpitonêyit ê-itêyimât onahâhkisîma
sentences.english: When he entered, as soon as the old man recognized his son-in-law, he helplessly twitched the muscles of his face, thinking of his son-in-law, “Let me greet him.”

sentences.original: yahôw, tânsi êkwah tiyôtahk kisêyiniw, konta kâ-ca-cîpotonêyit sakâw-iyiniw omanitôwiw ? itêw.
sentences.english: “Why, what is the old man doing, twisting his face that silly way, the manitou Bush Cree?” he asked him.

sentences.original: êkw ôki oskinîkiskwêwak ê-kakîsimototawâcik wîtimowâwa ta-kakwê-pimâcihâyit ohtâwiyiwâwa, namoya nântaw nka-kîh-tôtên, êka mâ manitôwiyân.
sentences.text: êkwa ôki oskinîkiskwêwak ê-kakîsimototawâcik wîtimowâwa ta-kakwê-pimâcihâyit ôhtâwiyiwâwa
sentences.english: Then, when those young women implored their brother-in-law to try to restore their father to life, “I cannot do anything, since of course I have no manitou power.

sentences.original: wiya kôhtâwiyiwâw manitôwiw, kahkiyaw awiya êh-itikot sakâw-iyiniwa, itêw, êkos êh-ati-wayawît, êh-kîwêt.
sentences.english: It is your father has  manitou power, as all the Bush Cree say of him,” he told them, and  with that left the tent and went home.
So much for this.
When autumn came, the old man died.
Likewise his daughter soon died.
Now, this is the end of the story.
